questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient came with complaints of nausea, vomiting, giddiness, and drowsiness since one day. On further inquiry, you find out there is a history of similar complaints in the family members who recently consumed food prepared with grains as shown in the image. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image showing wheat grains infested with blackish fungal mass are suggestive of ergotism.

Ergot or Claviceps purpurae is a field fungus. Foodgrains like bajra, rye, sorghum, and wheat have a tendency to get infested with ergot fungus. They grow as a blackish mass and the seeds become black and irregular. These get harvested along with the food grains and consumption of ergot-infested grain leads to ergotism.  

Acute cases present with nausea, vomiting, giddiness, and drowsiness for a period up to 24 to 48 hours after the ingestion of ergot grain. In cases of chronic consumption, the present with painful cramps in limbs, and peripheral gangrene due to vasoconstriction of capillaries.

questions.text: An estimate of the poverty line is the expenditure required, in urban areas, for a daily calorie intake of _________ per person.
questions.solution:
An estimate of the poverty line is the expenditure required for a daily calorie intake of 2100 in urban areas and 2400 in rural areas, per person.

Income-based poverty line in India is per capita expenditure of Rs. 47 in urban areas and Rs. 32 in rural areas per day.

questions.text: A patient files a case in the district consumer court alleging medical negligence. If he wins the case, what would be the maximum compensation that this court can dispense?
questions.solution:
If the patient wins the case in the district consumer court, the maximum compensation that can be given is upto Rs. 20 lakhs.

A complaint against the medical professional can be filed in the consumer court. It should contain all the details of the case, an expert certificate or opinion from the doctor of concerned speciality. It should state the complaint is prima facie true and needs further investigation. It should aslo specify the amount demanded.

These courts can only give compensation. The monetary limits of the compensation that can be granted by the consumer courts are

  • District Consumer Court - up to Rs. 20 lakhs
  • State Commission - Rs. 20 lakhs to Rs. 1 crore
  • National Commission - above Rs. 1 crore.

questions.text: The instrument  given below is most widely used to measure:
questions.solution:
The given image is of a dry and wet bulb hygrometer. It is the most widely used instrument for measuring the humidity of air. 

A dry and wet bulb hygrometer consists of two identical thermometers - a dry bulb thermometer and a wet-bulb thermometer, mounted side by side on a stand. 

After obtaining the readings of both thermometers, the corresponding relative humidity can be found from psychrometric charts and slides. 

Other instruments used to measure humidity are:

  • Sling psychrometer
  • Assman psychrometer

Other options:

Option B- The mean radiant temperature is measured using a globe thermometer.

Option C- The cooling power of air was originally measured using a kata thermometer. Kata thermometer is now largely used for recording low air velocities. 

Option D- The maximum temperature reached in a given time is measured by a maximum thermometer. The thermometer is set each time by swinging briskly.

questions.text: Lice are not vectors of:
questions.solution:
• Q fever is spread by inhalation of contaminated aerosols containing Coxiella burnetii arising from the placenta or parturient fluids of infected livestock or from contaminated secretions and birth fluids on the surface of newborn animals.
  • Soft ticks are the most common reservoirs of Q fever.

questions.text: A replacement surgery was conducted on a patient, as he had malfunctioning of the instrument shown in the below image. According to biomedical waste management, which of the following colored boxes should the instrument be disposed of in?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a metallic pacemaker and it should be discarded in the blue color box.

All metallic body implants except metallic sharps are discarded in the blue box. Metallic sharps are discarded in white color or translucent boxes.

Other wastes discarded in the blue box are:

  • Glassware- broken or discarded
  • Contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampoules except those contaminated with cytotoxic wastes.

All items contaminated with cytotoxic drugs along with their glass or plastic ampoules and vials are discarded in the yellow boxes along with the cytotoxic drugs.

Treatment or disposal options of wastes in the blue box are:

  • Disinfection with detergent and sodium hypochlorite treatment, or
  • Autoclaving, or
  • Microwaving, or
  • Hydroclaving 

They are then sent for recycling.

Different colored bins used in biomedical waste management are yellow, red, white, and blue.

questions.text: Which of the following is a nodal centre in case of disaster management?
questions.solution:
In the district, a body called the District Disaster Management Authority is responsible for disaster management. It is chaired by either, the District Collector, District Magistrate or the Deputy Commissioner.

Chief Medical Officer of the district is a part of this authority.

questions.text: Pre-placement examination has an important role in
questions.solution: Pre-placement Examination is done at the time of employment and includes workers’ history (medical, family, occupational and social), physical examination and radiological examination. It is the foundation of an efficient occupational health service. The main purpose of Pre-placement Examination is to place ‘the right man in the right job’(Ergonomics); so that worker can perform his duties efficiently without detriment to his health.

questions.text: Total communication (TC) is used for _______.
questions.solution: The philosophy of total communication is used in the education of deaf children. It requires incorporation of aural, oral, and manual modes of communication for effective communication with and among hearing-impaired people.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman who recently lost her only son wants to conceive again. She visited the genetic counseling center as she was worried about her advanced age. What is the risk of giving birth to a baby with Down's syndrome in this woman?
questions.solution:
The risk of giving birth to a baby with Down's syndrome at the time of conception in this lady who is 45 years old is 1 in 50.

Down’s syndrome is an autosomal disorder. It was described by Langdon Down in 1866. It is also called trisomy 21 or mongolism. The clinical features of Down's syndrome seen in older children are:

  • Short stature
  • Small round head
  • Narrow tilted eye slits
  • Mal-formed ears
  • Short broad hands
  • Lax limbs
  • Mental retardation
  • Congenital abnormalities like cardiac defects and atresia of the alimentary tract.

The frequency of Down's syndrome increases with rising maternal age. The risk of a woman who is 20 is 1 in 3000 but that of a woman who is 45 is 1 in 50.

It seems to be unaffected by the age of the father.

Note: Genetic counseling: It can either be prospective or retrospective. Prospective genetic counseling refers to the prevention of disease by the prevention or reduction of heterozygous marriage like in sickle cell anemia or thalassemia. Retrospective genetic counseling means that the hereditary disorder has already occurred in the family and methods like contraception, pregnancy termination or sterilization are to be used to avoid any serious health disorder in the unborn baby. 

Methods of early diagnosis and treatment are early detection of genetic carriers, prenatal diagnosis, screening of newborn infants, and recognizing pre-clinical cases.

questions.text: Which of the following drug is used for the management of small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO) is :
questions.solution:
Rifaximin is the preferred drug for the management of small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO).

The other drugs used are :

  • Tetracyclines
  • Cephalosporins
  • Metronidazole
  • Amoxicillin-Clavulanic acid

The antibiotics are given for around 3 weeks.

Rifaximin is the antibiotic used in hepatic encephalopathy to lower blood ammonia levels.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented to the clinic with the lesions shown below. She has been taking oral contraceptive pills. Identify the following lesions?
questions.solution:
The lesions shown in the image are spider naevi. They are seen in:

  • Estrogen excess states such as pregnancy and OCP use
  • Chronic liver disease - especially alcoholic liver disease
  • Thyrotoxicosis

They are vascular lesions characterized by the tortuous dilatation of arterioles just underneath the skin. On applying and releasing pressure over the lesion they typically fill from the center outward.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with recurrent episodes of headache, palpitation, and sweating. His BP is 160/100 mm Hg and heart rate is 130/min. 24-hour urinary metanephrines are elevated and CT abdomen shows a right suprarenal mass. He is scheduled for surgery. Which inhalational anesthetic is contraindicated in him?
questions.solution:
The given findings are suggestive of pheochromocytoma. Halothane is contraindicated in patients with pheochromocytoma.

Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine secreting tumor of chromaffin origin. Halothane sensitizes the heart to the arrhythmogenic effects of epinephrine.

Other anesthetic drugs to be avoided in a patient with pheochromocytoma are:

  • Succinylcholine - causes fasciculations which lead to raised intraabdominal pressure and catecholamine release from the tumor
  • Ketamine - sympathomimetic
  • Pancuronium - vagal blockade leading to tachycardia
  • Atracurium, tubocurarine - histamine release which may provoke catecholamine release

questions.text: Most common cause of hemolytic uremic syndrome in India is
questions.solution:
Most common cause of haemolytic uremic syndrome in India is shigella dysenteriae type I                                

Other causes of HUS:

  • Infections : Usually follows diarrheal diseases
    • Most common cause in World is E.coli O157:H7
    • Most common cause in India is shigella dysentriae type I
  • Autoimmunity
  • Complement activation ( in atypical HUS )

questions.text: Which of the following is used in the management of tumor lysis syndrome?
questions.solution:
Rasburicase - recombinant urate oxidase is used in the management of tumor lysis syndrome(TLS). TLS is associated with hyperuricemia and rasburicase helps in decreasing the levels of uric acid in the blood.

Management of TLS includes:

  • Aggressive hydration
  • Allopurinol
  • Urinary alkalinization with sodium bicarbonate (controversial)
  • Rasburicase - recombinant urate oxidase.

However, rituximab, gemtuzumab, and alemtuzumab are monoclonal antibodies that cause a rapid fall in circulating tumor cells upon infusion and may lead to TLS.

questions.text: Which of the following casts are associated with a poor prognosis?
questions.solution:
Broad casts are associated with a poor prognosis.

They refer to wider waxy casts that are seen in advanced chronic kidney disease. It implies dilation of the tubules.

Epithelial casts consist of large epithelial cells and are seen in acute tubular necrosis, and acute interstitial nephritis.

WBC casts consist of leukocytes and is seen in pyelonephritis and acute interstitial nephritis. 

Hyaline casts are seen in non-specific conditions and prerenal failure.

questions.text: Automatic implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) implantation is done for all of the following conditions except:

choices.text: Acute coronary syndrome with low ejection fraction

questions.solution:
An automated implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (AICD) is a device placed in the chest or abdomen to detect arrhythmias and perform cardioversion, defibrillation, and pace the heart.

It is contraindicated in patients experiencing tachyarrhythmias with reversible or transient causes such as acute MI.

It is used in: 

  • Brugada syndrome- refers to a sodium channelopathy with a high risk of arrhythmias that can lead to sudden cardiac death.
  • Ventricular fibrillation and ventricular tachycardia.
  • Cardiac resynchronization therapy for prevention of sudden cardiac death in heart failure.
  • High-risk situations of sudden cardiac death in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: Pyridoxine co-administration is essential for which of the following drugs used for treating Wilson’s disease?
questions.solution:
Pyridoxine co-administration is essential for the Penicillamine drug used for treating Wilson’s disease.

Wilson's disease is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by defective hepatic copper excretion, leading to copper accumulation in the liver, brain, and other organs. It typically presents in adolescents or young adults with hepatic symptoms such as hepatitis, cirrhosis, or liver failure, or with neurological manifestations including tremors, dystonia, dysarthria, and psychiatric disturbances. Kayser-Fleischer rings, copper deposits in the cornea, are a hallmark finding. Diagnosis is confirmed by low serum ceruloplasmin, elevated urinary copper excretion, and genetic testing. Treatment includes copper-chelating agents like penicillamine or trientine(Option C), along with zinc therapy(Option A) to reduce intestinal copper absorption. Early detection and lifelong treatment can prevent disease progression and complications.

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement concerning massive blood transfusions.

choices.text: Dilution of coagulation factors and platelets will occur following massive blood transfusions
The most common cause of death after massive blood transfusion is coagulopathy
Acidosis in a patient receiving a large volume transfusion is more likely to be the result of inadequate treatment of hypovolaemia than due to the effects of transfusion
Platelet concentrates have to be transfused prophylactically in patients receiving large-volume blood transfusions

questions.solution:
The prophylactic use of platelet concentrates in patients receiving large-volume blood transfusions is currently not recommended.

Platelet function is rapidly lost during the storage of whole blood and there is virtually no platelet function after 24 hours.
Platelet concentrates are given only when:

  1. The patient shows clinical signs of microvascular bleeding: i.e. bleeding and oozing from mucous membranes, wounds, raw surfaces, and catheter sites
  2. The patient’s platelet count falls below 50 x 109/L.

Platelet transfusion is considered in cases where the platelet count falls below 20 x 109/L, even if there is no clinical evidence of bleeding as there is a danger of hidden bleeding into the brain tissue.

Other options:
Option A: Dilution of coagulation factors and platelets will occur following massive blood transfusions as plasma undergoes progressive loss of coagulation factors during storage, particularly Factors V and VIII unless stored at –25°C or colder. Therefore, massive or large volume transfusions result in disorders of coagulation.

Option B: The most common cause of death after a massive blood transfusion is dilutional coagulopathy.

Option C: Acidosis in massive blood transfusion is mostly because of the inadequate treatment of hypovolaemia rather than due to the effects of blood transfusion.

questions.text: Which of the following hereditary sensory and autonomic neuropathies (HSANs) presents with ‘burning feet syndrome’?
questions.solution:
There are five types of hereditary sensory and autonomic neuropathies (HSAN I–V).

HSAN I is shows autosomal dominant inheritance and often presents as a distal small-fiber neuropathy (burning feet syndrome) associated with sensory loss and foot ulcers.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the treatment of irritable bowel syndrome?

choices.text: It includes patient counselling and dietary alterations
Diet low in FODMAPs reduces symptoms in IBS patients
High fiber diets and bulking agents are used  to improve symptoms

questions.solution:
Anti flatulence medication is not frequently used to relieve the symptoms of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). FODMAPs are poorly absorbed in the small intestine.

FODMAPs stands for Fermentable Oligosaccharides, Disaccharides, Monosaccharides And Polyols. Foodstuff containing lactose, fructose and sorbitol are some examples of FODMAPs.

Since FODMAPs are poorly absorbed, they are fermented by gut bacteria in the colon to produce gas and osmotically active carbohydrates. So, a diet low in FODMAPs is recommended to reduce symptoms in IBS patients.

questions.text: Henoch Schonlein puprura is also known as___
questions.solution:
Henoch Schonlein purpura is also known as IgA vasculitis. It is a small vessel vasculitis that occurs due to the IgA immune complex deposition within the wall of the blood vessels. It is commonly seen in children and is characterized by:

  • Palpable purpura without thrombocytopenia and coagulopathy
  • Arthralgia- commonly affecting hip, knee, or ankle joints
  • Abdominal pain
  • Glomerulonephritis.

The skin biopsy will show small vessel vasculitis, with IgA and C3 deposition in the affected organs by immunofluorescence.

questions.text: A newly diagnosed HIV patient presented with fever, cough, and hemoptysis. His sputum sample showed acid-fast bacilli. What is the appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Start ART and then ATT after 2 weeks
Start ATT and then ART after 2 weeks

questions.solution:
In a patient with HIV and TB start ATT first and then start ART as soon as ATT is tolerated (between 2 weeks and 2 months) by the patient. This is done in order to avoid immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS). 

Immune Reconstitution Inflammatory Syndrome (IRIS):

Patients with HIV-related TB may experience a temporary paradoxical exacerbation of symptoms and radiographic manifestations of TB after starting ATT. This occurs as a result of immune reconstitution due to simultaneous administration of ART and ATT.

It is characterized by high fever, lymphadenopathy, expanding intra-thoracic lesions, and worsening of chest x-ray findings. Diagnosis should be made only after ruling out treatment failure and other infections. For severe cases, prednisone 1-2mg/kg is used for 1-2 weeks and then gradually tapered.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a mode of transmission of SARS-CoV-2?
questions.solution:
Vector-borne transmission is not a mode of transmission of SARS-CoV-2.

The modes of transmission of SARS-CoV-2 are

  • Droplet transmission 
    • It is a type of direct transmission which occurs when someone coughs, sneezes, speaks or spits.
    • The virus-containing droplets from the infected person travel shortly in air and directly contact another person’s conjunctiva, oral or nasal mucosa.
    • This is usually limited to a distance of about 6 feet between the source and the host.
    • The particle size here is 5-10 µm in diameter.
  • Fomite transmission 
    • It is a type of indirect transmission.
    • Fomites are objects other than water or food contaminated by infectious agents that include clothes, towels, linen, cups, spoons, pencils, books, toys, door handles, taps, etc.
    • The transmission occurs when one touches the contaminated objects and touches his mouth, nose, or eyes.
  • Airborne - droplet nuclei transmission 
    • It is a type of indirect transmission.
    • Droplet nuclei are the dried residue of droplets of size <5µm that are generated by the evaporation of droplets coughed or sneezed into the air and by a variety of atomizing devices.
    • They can remain infectious when suspended in the air over long distances(>6m) and time(typically hours).
    • The transmission occurs when one inhales droplet nuclei/aerosols containing the virus in sufficient quantity.

questions.text: The receptor used by the SARS-CoV-2 to gain entry into cells is
questions.solution:
Angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE-2) is the specific functional receptor for SARS-CoV-2 in human cells. 

SARS-CoV-2 enters the host cell by binding to ACE2 receptors on the membrane of the host cell. ACE2 is expressed in nearly all human organs in varying degrees.

In the respiratory system, ACE2 is mainly expressed by the type 2 alveolar epithelial cells in the highest quantity. Hence, the primary target of SARS-CoV-2 is type 2 alveolar cells.

questions.text: ________ refers to the sexual orientation in which a person is emotionally and sexually attracted to people regardless of gender.
questions.solution:
Pansexual refers to the sexual orientation in which a person is emotionally and sexually attracted to people regardless of gender.

As doctors, to better serve LGBT (lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender) patients and provide comfortable and more competent sexual health care it is important to understand terminology relating to the LGBT community. This will help to bridge the gap in healthcare that exists for this community due to lack of awareness, stigma and discrimination.

Other options-

Option (A): Bisexual refers to the sexual orientation in which the person is emotionally and sexually attracted to people of their own gender as well as those of other genders.

Option (B): Asexual refers to those people who experience very little to no sexual attraction towards others.

Option (D): Heterosexual refers to the sexual orientation in which people are attracted emotionally and sexually to the opposite gender i.e. women are attracted to men and men are attracted to women.

questions.text: As a healthcare worker working in a COVID hospital, you receive the following vaccine. Which of the following is not an adverse event related to this vaccine?
questions.solution:
Demyelinating disorders are rare adverse events following Covishield, not Covaxin.

 

Composition of Covaxin:

  • Inactivated coronavirus
  • Aluminium hydroxide gel
  • TLR 7/8 agonist
  • 2-Phenoxyethanol and
  • Phosphate Buffered Saline/ NKA1

 Adverse effects:

 Covaxin Covishield

Fever, cough, sweating

 Fever and chills

Injection site pain and swelling

 Injection site pain and swelling

Headache, bodyache, fatigue

 Headache, malaise, fatigue

Abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting

 Nausea

Dizziness, giddiness, tremor

Myalgia, arthralgia

Rarely, complications like demyelinating disorders, Guillain-Barre syndrome and vaccine-induced immune thrombotic thrombocytopenia (VITT) are also seen following Covishield vaccine.

questions.text: The Gold's criteria for very severe COPD is:
questions.solution:
The Gold's criteria for very severe COPD (stage IV) is FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 < 30%.  

The severity of COPD is assessed by Global Initiative for Lung Disease (GOLD) classification:  

GOLD Stage Severity Spirometry
I Mild FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥80% predicted
II Moderate FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥50% but <80% predicted
III Severe FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted
IV Very severe FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <30% predicted

questions.text: Which of the following is true about paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)?
questions.solution:
Deficiency of CD55 and CD59 is seen in paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH).

PNH is an acquired chronic hemolytic anemia with persistent intravascular hemolysis.

It is due to an acquired mutation in the X-linked phosphatidylinositol class A PIG-A gene causing deficiency of GPI. GPI is a glycolipid that anchors membrane protective factors such as CD59 and CD55 to the membrane. The deficiency of CD55 and CD59 makes the RBC sensitive to complement-mediated intravascular hemolysis.

PNH is characterized by hemolytic anemia, pancytopenia, and venous thrombosis involving cerebral, hepatic, renal, portal, and abdominal veins.

PNH is diagnosed using flow cytometry.

Note-

The tendency of red cells to lyse at night is explained by a slight decrease in blood pH during sleep. This increases the activity of complement.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with increased forgetfulness and awareness for the past few months. Which of the following would be a striking feature to distinguish Lewy body dementia from Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution: Visuospatial hallucinations are a pathognomonic feature seen in Diffuse Lewy body disease. They are recurrent, well-formed, and detailed. They are present in more than ⅔rd of these patients. At present, visual hallucination is the most useful clinical feature to distinguish it from Alzheimer’s disease. Insight may or may not be retained, depending on the degree of cognitive impairment.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male patient presents with steatorrhea and ataxia. Acanthocytes were seen on the peripheral blood smear. The disease is thought to be because of abnormal chylomicron formation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is abetalipoproteinemia.

Abetalipoproteinemia is a rare genetic disorder in which there is defective chylomicron formation. Chylomicrons are required for the absorption and transport of fats and fat-soluble vitamins.

It presents in early childhood with steatorrhoea, hypolipidemia, failure to thrive, ataxia, sensory and motor neuropathies.

questions.text:
A patient with uncontrolled hypertension and creatinine- 4.5 mg/dL was found to have unequal sized kidneys. Renal USG shows right kidney 9cm and left kidney 7cm in size. There was no evidence of any obstruction. The investigation of choice for the patient is______

IVP-intravenous pyelogram
questions.solution:
In this clinical scenario, a patient presents with uncontrolled hypertension, a creatinine level of 4.5 mg/dL, and a renal ultrasound showing a right kidney measuring 9 cm and a left kidney measuring 7 cm, with no signs of obstruction. The preferred investigation for this patient is an isotope renogram.

The most appropriate initial imaging test for a patient with hypertension and elevated creatinine is an abdominal ultrasound to assess renal size and morphology. If the ultrasound reveals a size discrepancy >1 cm between the kidneys, potential causes include unilateral developmental abnormalities, underlying disease processes, or renovascular disease leading to arterial insufficiency.

The diagnosis of renovascular hypertension can be made by Doppler ultrasound of the renal vasculature. As it is not given in the option the next choice for a patient with increased creatinine is an isotope renogram.

After USG, the next investigation of choice would be, Doppler USG  >  Isotope renogram  >  MRI studies.

Other options:

Option B: MR angiography cannot be done as there is a risk of nephrogenic fibrosis with gadolinium in patients with increased creatinine.

Option C: Retrograde pyelography is used for vesicoureteral reflux and would not be helpful. Obstruction is already ruled out. 

Option D: IVP(Intravenous pyelogram) is not done these days due to the risk of anaphylaxis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with dizziness and palpitations since 3 days. On examination, she has an irregularly irregular pulse with ECG findings as shown below. If she were to undergo surgical ablation to treat this condition, which part of the myocardium should to be targeted?

choices.text: Across the bicuspid annulus from left atrium to  free wall of the ventricle
From the AV node towards the tricuspid annulus
Left atrial regions around the pulmonary veins

questions.solution:
The given history and the ECG findings of an irregularly irregular rhythm, absent p waves, and narrow QRS complexes are suggestive of atrial fibrillation. If she were to undergo surgical ablation to treat this condition, the left atrial regions around the pulmonary veins should be targeted.

The triggering foci for atrial fibrillation are most commonly originate from the left atrial tissue near the openings of the pulmonary veins. When medical management is unsuccessful or if quicker results are desired, cardiac ablation can be carried out. Targeting this region will produce the best results.

 ECG shows an increased rate and irregular rhythm with the absence of p waves. The CHA2 DS2 -VASc score can be used to determine a patient's risk of developing stroke, and if the score is >2, the patient is recommended to start oral anticoagulation therapy. Beta-blockers and calcium channel blockers are most commonly used to treat atrial fibrillation, and they help to control the ventricular rate and improve symptoms. 

Other options:

Option A: The accessory pathway in Wolff Parkinson White is most commonly found across the bicuspid annulus from the left atrium to the free wall of the left ventricle, followed by posteroseptal and anteroseptal.

Option B: AV nodal re-entrant tachycardia circuits are most commonly found along the path from the AV node to the tricuspid valve annulus.

Option C: Atrial flutter most commonly originates around the cavotricuspid isthmus, and ablation of this area can resolve the condition in most people.

questions.text: A physician is in Africa, working with the Doctors Without Borders group. He encounters a 7-year-old boy with the following finding. His parents say that he had a jaw swelling for 2 months that failed to resolve with antibiotics. A biopsy of the swelling reveals a starry sky appearance. Which of the following statements is true about this patient's condition?

choices.text: It is associated with n-myc dysregulation
Expectant management is the treatment of choice
It is associated with HIV infection

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of the endemic type of Burkitt's lymphoma. In this condition, the tumor cells are CD21+.

Burkitt's lymphoma is an aggressive condition and is the most common NHL in children. This condition is endemic in African countries and is associated with Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection. It is associated with c-myc dysregulation, especially in cases in bone marrow involvement.

Patients require aggressive management with high-dose chemotherapy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with daytime sleepiness and impaired concentration and memory. On examination, his BMI is 41 kg/m2, blood pressure is 160/100 mm of Hg. His awake arterial blood gas analysis shows bicarbonate - 30 mEq/L, PaCO2 - 50 mmHg,  PaO2 - 66 mmHg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis of this patient with awake high pCO2, low pO2, and BMI of 41 is obesity hypoventilation syndrome.

Obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) or Pickwickian syndrome is defined as the presence of awake alveolar hypoventilation in an obese individual which cannot be attributed to other conditions associated with alveolar hypoventilation.

Patients with OHS are obese and give a history of daytime hypersomnolence, loud snoring, choking during sleep fatigue, impaired concentration and memory, a small oropharynx, and a thick neck.

OHS may be associated with the following findings:

  • Elevated serum bicarbonate (>27 mEq/L)
  • Hypercapnia (PaCO2 >45 mmHg)
  • Hypoxemia (PaO2 <70 mmHg)
  • Polycythemia

Other options:

  • In obstructive sleep apnea, the awake ABG values are usually normal.
  • There is no ABG changes in narcolepsy.
  • History is not suggestive of COPD.

questions.text:
The hyperpigmentation associated with Addison's disease is due to which of the following?

POMC: pro-opiomelanocortin

GnRH: gonadotropin-releasing hormone

TSH: thyroid-stimulating hormone
questions.solution:
The hyperpigmentation associated with Addison's disease is due to increased serum levels of POMC (pro-opiomelanocortin).

Addison's disease is a primary adrenal insufficiency in which the adrenal is unable to secrete adequate amounts of cortisol (glucocorticoid), aldosterone (mineralocorticoid), and sex hormones. The most common cause of Addison's disease is autoimmune adrenalitis. 

Inadequate adrenal hormone secretion will result in positive feedback to the pituitary, leading to increased ACTH (adrenocorticotropic releasing hormone) secretion. ACTH happens to be derived from a precursor compound known as POMC (pro-opiomelanocortin). POMC breaks down to form ACTH and MSH (melanocyte-stimulating hormone). This MSH is responsible for the hyperpigmentation seen in Addison's disease.

  

The image below shows a woman before (right) and after (left) developing Addison's disease. You can see how she has lost weight, become anorexic, and developed hyperpigmentation of the skin-

 

The diagnosis of primary adrenal insufficiency can be made with the short cosyntropin test. Elevated ACTH levels help to differentiate it from secondary causes, which would show low ACTH levels. Primary adrenal insufficiency will also have a compensatory elevation in renin levels due to decreased aldosterone in the body.

Treatment is with a combination of glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and sex hormone replacement depending on the patient's symptoms and requirement.

Other options-

Option (B): GnRH has no relation to ACTH or MSH production.

Option (C): Cortisol levels will be low in Addison's disease. This is the cause for feedback elevation in ACTH, not the cause for hyperpigmentation.

Option (D): TSH does not cause hyperpigmentation. However, in Grave's disease, the hyperthyroid state results in faster cortisol metabolism. This results in an elevated ACTH due to positive feedback, which can again lead to hyperpigmentation by the production of MSH from POMC by the same mechanism described above.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with bluish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes. All of the following findings may be responsible for the given symptoms except:
questions.solution:
Bluish discoloration of the skin and mucous membranes is suggestive of cyanosis. Cyanosis is not seen when reduced hemoglobin is 2 gm%, it becomes apparent when the concentration of reduced hemoglobin exceeds 4 gm/dL.

Cyanosis is detectable with methemoglobin ≥ 1.5 gm% and/or sulfhemoglobin ≥ 0.5 gm%.

Central cyanosis is detectable when the oxygen saturation falls to 85%. In dark-skinned people, it may be detectable at the oxygen saturation of 75%.

The types of cyanosis are:

Central cyanosis Peripheral cyanosis

Due to diminished arterial oxygen saturation/presence of abnormal hemoglobin derivative.

Due to diminished peripheral blood flow.

Mucous membranes and skin are both affected

 Mucous membranes of the oral cavity or those beneath the tongue are spared.

Decreases after O2 supplementation

 Does not decrease after O2 supplementation

questions.text: The approximate time interval between HIV infection & manifestation of AIDS is?
questions.solution:
The time interval between HIV infection and the manifestation of AIDS is 10 years.

The time interval mentioned here is the incubation period of AIDS and is estimated at approximately 10 years for young adults.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not applicable to rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis?

choices.text: Hyperglycemia is a major risk factor
CT scan is used for definitive diagnosis
Cavernous sinus thrombosis is seen in advanced cases
Liposomal amphotericin B is the drug of choice

questions.solution:
CT scan is not used for the definitive diagnosis of rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis. The investigation of choice, in this case, is endoscopic biopsy followed by histopathological examination.

The most accurate site for such biopsies is the middle turbinate. Histopathological analysis of the biopsy sample will reveal charachteristic hyphal findings of the fungus causing mucormycosis. Rhizopus is the most commonly implicated organism in mucormycosis. 

 

CT scans of the head and sinuses do not yield findings that are specific for mucormycosis (indistinguishable from those seen in bacterial sinusitis). This makes it an ineffective investigation of choice. 

Other options

Option A - Hyperglycemia is a major risk factor in mucormycosis. It disrupts normal iron sequestration and phagocytic action and promotes tissue penetration of the fungus. This effect is compounded in states of diabetic ketoacidosis. 

Option C - Rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis is characterized by complications such as cavernous sinus thrombosis when advanced cases are encountered. Clinical features suggestive of cavernous sinus thrombosis are bilateral proptosis, chemosis, vision loss, and impairment of extraocular muscle function (ophthalmoplegia). 

Option D - Mucormycosis is primarily managed by the administration of a polyene antifungal drug. The liposomal formulation of amphotericin B (LAmB) is the drug of choice in CNS infections. It has proven efficacy due to good penetration. The initial dosage is 5 mg/kg per day and it can be escalated to 7.5-10 mg/kg per day.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding common LGBT terminologies and definitions?

choices.text: Bisexual - A person who is emotionally and sexually attracted to people of their own gender and people of other genders
Cisgender - A person whose gender identity and assigned sex at birth correspond
Asexual - A person identifying as having no gender
Gender identity - A person’s internal sense of being a man/male, woman/female, both, neither, or another gender.

questions.solution:
Asexual: A person experiencing little or no sexual attraction to others.

Agender: A person identifying as having no gender.

 While social and cultural acceptance of the LGBT(Lesbian,Gay, Bisexual and Transgender) community has improved in certain parts of the world, many LGBT individuals continue to experience discrimination, stigmatization, and violence. Inequitable healthcare policies and practices, lack of awareness to LGBT health issues, and limited understanding of the unique health needs of LGBT individuals contribute to decreased access to care and disparities in health outcomes for LGBT individuals.

Hospitals and clinics can take a number of steps to create a welcoming and safe space for LGBT patients. This starts by establishing and communicating a nondiscrimination policy that clearly includes gender identity, gender expression, and sexual orientation protections.

questions.text: Confirmatory test of choice for amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS)  is
questions.solution:
There is no single diagnostic test that can confirm or entirely exclude the diagnosis of motor neuron disease in general and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) in particular.

The diagnosis of ALS is based on clinical criteria that include the presence of upper motor neuron and lower motor neuron signs, the progression of the disease, and the absence of an alternative explanation.

Practically, the diagnosis is made when it is suggested by the history and physical examination, supported by electrodiagnostic studies (EMG & NCS), and not excluded by neuroimaging (MRI) and laboratory studies (CSF, blood, and urine analysis). Increased signal in the corticospinal tracts on T2-weighted MRI if seen is supportive the diagnosis of ALS

questions.text: MIDAS Questionnaire is used for__________
questions.solution:
The Migraine Disability Assessment Score (MIDAS) questionnaire was put together to help measure the impact migraine is having on patients' lives

Related Pearl: Simplified diagnostic criteria for migraine

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 h in patients with a normal physical examination, no other reasonable cause for the headache, and

At Least 2 of the following features

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

Plus at Least 1 of the following features

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

questions.text: Which of the following is a key transcription factor involved in the differentiation of mesenchymal preadipocytes to adipose cells?
questions.solution:
One of the key transcription factors involved in the differentiation of mesenchymal preadipocytes to adipose cells is the peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor γ (PPARγ). It is a nuclear receptor that also binds the thiazolidinedione class of insulin-sensitizing drugs used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Note: Saroglitazar has a dual action on PPARα and PPAR𝝲 receptors. It reduces blood sugar and lipid levels in diabetic patients.

questions.text: Which of the following is the principle behind the wound healing procedure shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The principal behind the wound healing procedure, as shown above, is negative pressure wound therapy.

Applying intermittent negative pressure of approximately -125 mmHg appears to hasten debridement and the formation of granulation tissue in chronic wounds and ulcers.

The negative pressure may act by decreasing oedema, by removing interstitial fluid and by increasing blood flow. As a result, bacterial counts decrease and cell proliferation increases, thereby creating a suitable bed for graft or flap cover.

questions.text: You are assisting a consultant in surgery and at the end of the procedure, you observe him apply sutures in a manner shown in the image below. Identify the suturing technique depicted:.
questions.solution:
Subcuticular sutures have been depicted in the image.

In this technique of suturing, the suture is anchored at one end of the wound. Small bites of subcuticular tissue are taken on alternate sides of the wound and then pulled together gently at the apex. This approximates the wound edges together. The final bite leaves a trailing loop of the suture, and a knot can be tied.

The knots can be tied loosely or secured by means of a collar and bead when non-absorbable sutures are used. If the suture is absorbable, a buried knot is used.

This suturing technique is applied where cosmetic appearance is important and where skin edges are approximated easily.

Other options:

Option A: Interrupted sutures require the needle to penetrate the skin surface at a 90° angle. The distance from the needle to the edge of the wound should be approximately the same as the depth of the tissue being sutured. The suture is then tied using a surgeon's knot in case of nonabsorbable suture or a square knot for absorbable sutures.

The image below shows interrupted sutures.

Option C: Mattress sutures can either be vertical or horizontal. The initial suture is inserted as in an interrupted suture. The needle can then be moved either horizontally or vertically, traversing both edges of the wound once again. Such sutures are very useful in producing an accurate approximation of irregular wound edges. They can produce either eversion or inversion of a wound edge.

The images below show horizontal and vertical mattress sutures.

Option D: Continuous sutures are similar to interrupted sutures but unlike simple interrupted sutures, knots are not tied at every stitch. Only the first and last stitches are fixed by knotting.

Initially, a simple interrupted stitch is placed at one end of the wound but the suture is knotted and not cut. Simple continuous sutures are placed over the length of the wound and each stitch should be placed at an equal distance. The application is terminated by a single knot at the end of the suture line.

questions.text: All are risk factors for breast carcinoma except ______

choices.text: Early age of first live child birth

questions.solution:
Early age of first live child birth and breast feeding are protective factors for carcinoma of the breast.

Related Pearl: Risk factors and protective factors for breast carcinoma

Risk factors

  • Age: Incidence increases with increasing age.
  • Sex: more common in females.
  • Family history of breast cancer
  • Race, ethnicity (white women have increased risk compared to women of other races)
  • History of radiation exposure
  • Mammographically dense breast
  • Genetic factors:
  • Mutations in tumor suppressor genes
    • BRCA 1
    • BRCA 2
    • TP53
    • CHEK2
  • Hereditary syndromes
    • Li Fraumeni syndrome
    • Cowden’s syndrome
    • HNPCC syndrome
    • Peutz-Jegher’s syndrome
    • Ataxia telangiectasia
  • Hormonal factors (hyperestrogenemia is the risk factor)
    • Early menarche
    • Late menopause
    • First full-term pregnancy >30 years
    • Nulliparity
    • Obesity (postmenopausal)
  • Higher socioeconomic status, high fat diet, alcohol intake

 

Protective factors

  • Early age at first pregnancy
  • Multiparity
  • Breastfeeding
  • Oophorectomy
  • Exercise
  • Tamoxifen and Aromatase inhibitors

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman with a breast lump was categorised as BI-RADS 4. What is the next best step in management?

BI-RADS - Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System
questions.solution:
The best option for further management would be tissue diagnosis by biopsy.

A BI-RADS category 4 is indicative of a suspicious abnormality with the likelihood of malignancy being 2% to 95%. Therefore, the next best step would be a tissue diagnosis by biopsy for ruling out/ confirmation of the malignancy.

The Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System or BI-RADS is used to categorize the degree of suspicion of malignancy for a mammographic abnormality. This is helpful when mammographic abnormalities that cannot be detected by the patient's physical examination include clustered microcalcifications and areas of abnormal density that have not yielded a palpable finding.

Other options:

Option A: Annual screening is usually done for BI-RADS category 1 and 2. BI-RADS 1 means that there are no masses, suspicious calcifications or areas of architectural distortion on mammography. BI-RADS 2 is consistent with benign findings including secretory calcifications, simple cysts, fat-containing lesions, calcified fibroadenomas, implants and intramammary lymph nodes.

Option B: Bi-annual screening is done for BI-RADS category 3. BI-RADS 3 includes a non-palpable, circumscribed mass or a solitary group of punctate calcifications on a mammogram.

Option D: Surgical excision/lumpectomy is done for BI-RADS category 6 which indicates a known, biopsy-proven malignancy.

questions.text: Identify the procedure shown in the video below.
questions.solution:
The above illustration shows Lahey's method of thyroid palpation.

Lahey's Method: The lobes are pushed to one side for palpation. For palpating the left lobe, the examiner should push the lobe laterally by the left hand and the lobe is palpated with the right hand.

Other options:

  • Crile's Method: The patient is asked to swallow while palpating the gland with the thumb, with the gland between the thumb and other fingers.
  • Kocher's Method: it is done to demonstrate the pressure effect of the thyroid gland on the trachea or larynx. Lateral compression will result in stridor.
  • Pemberton's sign: Obstruction to the major veins in the thorax causes engorgement of neck veins. This sign becomes obvious when the patients are asked to raise the hands above the head and the arms touch the ears. This is known as Pemberton’s sign.

questions.text: A hemithyroidectomy is being performed on a patient who has a follicular neoplasm as per her FNAC report.  A frozen section is sent to the pathologist during the procedure. Which of the following features, if seen will diagnose her condition as a follicular carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Capsular or vascular invasion confirms the presence of follicular carcinoma.

Fine needle aspiration cytology cannot differentiate between the follicular adenoma and follicular carcinoma. Hence, if the FNAC shows the presence of follicular neoplasm, hemithyroidectomy is performed. The frozen section of the excised specimen has to be evaluated. The presence of capsular or vascular invasion confirms the presence of follicular carcinoma.

Other features like nuclear polymorphism, atypia, and prominent nucleoli can be present in follicular adenoma.

Hurthle cell change refers to the increased eosinophilic granular cytoplasm in the neoplastic cells. It can be seen in both follicular carcinoma and adenoma.

questions.text: Which of these is the most common complications following hemorrhoidectomy?
questions.solution:
Urinary retention is the most common complication following hemorrhoidectomy. It is seen in 30% of the patients.

Other complications:

  • fecal incontinence (2%)
  • Infection (1%)
  • Delayed hemorrhage (1%)
  • Stricture (1%)

Patients typically recover quickly and are able to return to work within 1 to 2 weeks.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man underwent a diagnostic colonoscopy as a routine for colorectal cancer screening. Shortly a day later, he developed severe abdominal pain, distension, and vomiting. The per-abdomen examination showed rigidity and rebound tenderness. Further investigations revealed air beneath the diaphragm on the x-ray. The next best step in the management of this condition is?

choices.text: Closure of the colon with diversion

questions.solution:
In the given case, the patient has sustained iatrogenic colonoscopic perforation which has led to air under the diaphragm sign (seen in pneumoperitoneum). Since it's a surgical emergency and the patient has presented with symptoms, immediate laparoscopic exploration is the mainstay plan in managing these cases. 

Pneumoperitoneum results in diffuse abdominal pain, distension presenting acutely when the perforation is large. When this leak is contaminated, it leads to the development of secondary peritonitis (rigid abdomen and rebound tenderness) and is associated with significant mortality. 

Iatrogenic colonoscopic perforations typically occur by mechanical trauma (due to increased shaft tip pressure exerted), barotrauma (excessive air insufflation), or electrocautery injury (in therapeutic procedures).

questions.text: Choledochocele is __________
questions.solution:
Choledochocele represent Type III Choledochal Cyst, having dilation confined to the distal intrapancreatic portion of the common bile duct.

Choledochal cysts are cystic dilations of the common bile duct (CBD). They present with a triad of jaundice, a palpable upper quadrant mass and abdominal pain.

There are mainly five types of choledochal cysts as follows:

  • Type I : is a simple cyst that can involve any portion of the CBD.
  • Type II: It is described as an isolated diverticulum arising from the wall of the CBD, and joined to the CBD by a narrow stalk.
  • Type III: They have dilation confined to the distal intrapancreatic portion of the CBD and are also known as choledochocele.
  • Type IVA : The cysts consist of multiple dilatations of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type IVB: These choledochal cysts are multiple dilatations involving only the extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type V (Caroli’s disease): It consists of multiple dilatations limited to the intrahepatic bile ducts.

questions.text: Investigation of choice for acute pancreatitis is_______
questions.solution:
• Contrast-enhanced CT scan is the investigation of choice.
  • The optimal time for performing CECT is more than 72 h after the onset of symptoms (In the first 72 hours, CT may underestimate the extent of necrosis).

Acute pancreatitis is a condition characterized by inflammatory damage to the pancreas. Various causes of acute pancreatitis are:

  • Gall stone induced (most common cause)
  • Alcohol (2nd most common cause)
  • Trauma (most common cause in children)
  • Iatrogenic- Post endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)
  • Drug-induced pancreatitis (Thiazides, Azathioprine, Anti-cancer drugs, etc)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Scorpion bite
  • Idiopathic

Clinical presentation of acute pancreatitis is characterized by epigastric pain radiating to the back which is relieved by bending forward, nausea, and vomiting. Acute hemorrhagic pancreatitis can present with certain named signs like:

  • Cullen’s sign: Discoloration around the umbilicus
  • Grey Turner’s sign: Discoloration in the flanks
  • Fox sign: Discoloration in the inguinal region
  • Bryant’s sign: Discoloration on the scrotum

Blood investigations show increased serum amylase and lipase levels. Serum lipase is more sensitive and specific than serum amylase but it rises late. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) is the investigation of choice. Various scoring systems are used to grade the severity of acute pancreatitis based on blood investigations and radiographic findings.

The severity of pancreatitis detected on CT is staged according to the Balthazar criteria.

Related Pearl: Computed Tomography Severity Index (CTSI)/Balthazar Scoring for Acute Pancreatitis

 Balthazar Score

Balthazar Grade

Appearance on CT

CT Grade Points

Grade A

Normal CT

  0 Points
 

Grade B

 Focal or diffuse enlargement of the pancreas  1 Point
 

Grade C

 Pancreatic gland abnormalities and peripancreatic inflammation   2 Points

Grade D

 		 Fluid collection in a single location  3 Points
 

Grade E

 Two or more sites of fluid collection and/ or gas bubbles in, or adjacent to, the pancreas  4 Points
Necrosis Score  

Necrosis Percentage

  

Points

No necrosis

    

0 Points

 
 

0 to 30% necrosis

    

2 Points

 
 

30 to 50% necrosis

  

4 Points

 

 
 

Over 50% necrosis

    6 Points

 

The numerical Computed Tomography Severity Index (CTSI) has a maximum of 10 points, and it is the sum of the Balthazar grade points and pancreatic necrosis grade points.

questions.text: Nesbitt procedure is used for _____.
questions.solution:
The most common procedure used in Peyronie’s disease is the Nesbitt procedure.

This corrects the deformity by plicating the opposite side of the deformity, thereby straightening the penis.

Peyronie's disease is characterized by penile deformity, palpable penile plaques within the penis, erectile dysfunction and pain on erection.

Other options:

Option B: Marion's disease is a condition where hypertrophy of internal sphincter leads to bladder outlet obstruction.

Option C: Priapism means persistent erection lasting longer than 4 hours and it is a surgical emergency (in case of ischemic priapism).

Option D: Erectile dysfunction is consistent or recurrent inability to attain and/or maintain a penile erection sufficient for sexual satisfaction, which must persist for a minimum duration of 3 months for clinical diagnosis, except in cases of trauma or surgically-induced erectile dysfunction where the diagnosis can be made immediately.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy has been shifted to the operating room for the surgical correction of vesicoureteric reflux. Which of the following most commonly used intravesical technique for ureteric reimplantation?
questions.solution:
The most commonly used intravesical technique for ureteric re-implantation is the Cohen Cross-Trigonal technique.

Other options:

Option A: Politano-Leadbetter technique is the earliest known intravesical technique.

Option B: Glenn-Anderson technique is an intravesical technique, with considerably lesser complications.

Option D: Lich and Gregoir technique is an extravesical technique.

questions.text: Symptoms of thoracic outlet syndrome can be reproduced when the patient has both arms in the 90° abduction-external rotation position and asked to open and close the hands slowly over a 3-minute period. This provocative test is called?
questions.solution:
The test described in the question is a provocative test for thoracic outlet syndrome called Roos test (Extended arm stress test).

Roos test or EAST Test (Extended Arm Stress Test):

Method:

  • The patient has both arms in the 90° abduction-external rotation postion.
  • The patient is to open and close the hands slowly over a 3-minute period.

Inference:

  • Reproduction of symptoms suggests compression.

The following image below demonstrates the Roos test.

Provocative tests for Thoracic Outlet Syndrome:

Adson test (Scalene Manoeuvre):

Method:

The examiner locates the radial pulse and the patient is asked to:

  • Turn the head towards the affected side
  • Extend the neck
  • Take deep breath and hold

Inference:

A positive test is indicated by a disappearance of the pulse.

Halsted Test (Costoclavicular Manoeuvre):

Method:

  • The examiner locates the radial pulse and draws the patient's shoulder down and back as the patient lifts their chest in an exaggerated "attention" posture.

Inference:

  • A positive test is indicated by an absence of a pulse.

Wright Test (Hyperabduction Manoeuvre)

Method:

  • Patients arm is hyperabducted to 180o and externally rotated

Inference:

  • Loss of radial pulse suggests compression

Allen Test:

Method:

  • The patient is asked to clench both fists tightly for 1 minute at the same time.
  • Pressure is applied over both radial arteries simultaneously so as to occlude them.
  • The patient then opens the fingers of both hands rapidly, and the examiner compares the colour of both. The initial pallor should be replaced quickly by rubor.
  • The test may be repeated, this time occluding the ulnar arteries.

Inference:

  • If the artery is occluded, the colour does not return and pallor remains longer on the affected side.

questions.text: A child with blunt trauma to the abdomen is brought to the emergency department and found to have a splenic injury. He requires a total splenectomy. Which of the following organisms is not a cause of serious infection that can occur after splenectomy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Moraxella catarrhalis is not a cause of serious infection that can occur after total splenectomy in the above patient.

The most dreaded complication of a total splenectomy is overwhelming post-splenectomy infection (OPSI). It can usually occur within the first 2 to 3 years postoperatively. The spleen normally protects against infections by encapsulated bacteria. When patients undergo total splenectomy, they are at risk for postsplenectomy septicemia.

The microorganisms that can cause OPSI are as follows:

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Escherichia coli

The current standard of care in asplenic patients involves immunization with the 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV13) followed by the 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23) 8 weeks later. They should also be administered the H. influenzae type b conjugate and the quadrivalent meningococcal conjugate ACWY vaccine series. In the case of elective splenectomy, these vaccinations should be completed 10-12 weeks prior to surgery or at least 14 days before. In the case of emergency splenectomy, vaccination should be carried out 14 days after surgery to improve compliance.

questions.text: Most common site of obstruction in gallstone ileus is_____
questions.solution: The most common site of gallstone ileus is in the distal ileum, a few centimeters proximal to the ileocecal valve, where the caliber of the ileum decreases.

questions.text: What does the below-depicted image signify?
questions.solution:
The image shows Hutchinsons's nail sign in subungual melanoma. It arises from the nail matrix of big toe or thumb.

It is characterized by the extension of brown or black pigment from the nail bed, matrix, and nail plate to the adjacent cuticle and proximal or lateral nail folds. Also, it is associated with nail dystrophy.

Subungal hematoma is a close differential of subungual melanoma. It is seen secondary to trauma which causes bleeding and resultant hematoma formation and pigmentation. It is important to note that Hutchinson's nail sign is not seen with subungual hematoma.

Nodular melanoma is a condition where malignant melanoma cells proliferate downwards through the skin – this is known as vertical growth. The lesion presents as a nodule that has been rapidly enlarging.

Lentigo Maligna is an early form of melanoma, in which the malignant cells are confined to the tissue of origin, the epidermis, hence it is often reported as in-situ melanoma.

questions.text: For a patient in the emergency with suspected tension pneumothorax, bedside ultrasound was conducted. All of the following radiological signs confirm the diagnosis except?
questions.solution:
The seashore sign is indicative of normal lung sliding on an M-mode USG. In this, the waves of the sea represent the skin, subcutaneous layers, and parietal pleura. Distal to it, there is a granular appearance due to lung parenchyma, forming the shore. 

In pneumothorax, the air in the pleural cavity acts as a barrier to the ultrasound waves and reflects almost all of them. Thus, the seashore sign is absent here.

Normally, lung sliding in USG is due to the movement seen between two pleural layers during respiration. If it is absent, the grainy lung parenchyma underneath is replaced with white horizontal parallel lines known as the stratosphere sign or the barcode sign. This is seen in pneumothorax and indicates an absence of motion beneath the pleural lines.

questions.text: Proper functioning of ICD tube is indicated by?

choices.text: Continuous air bubbles coming out of the underwater drain
Oscillation of water column in the tube

questions.solution:
Functioning of the ICD tube can be confirmed by seeing the oscillation of water column in the tube. 

During spontaneous respiration, the water level rises with inspiration and falls with expiration. Whereas during positive pressure ventilation, the opposite occurs. This oscillation is also known as tidaling.

An intercostal tube (ICD) is placed along the 5th intercostal space (ICS) in midaxillary line in adults and in paediactric age group it is placed at at 2nd ICS mid-clavicular line.

Other options:

Option A: Continous bubbling indicates an air leak in the drainage system, which should be corrected.

Option B: Chest X-ray is useful for assessing the position of the ICD tube inside the chest, not its functioning.

Option C: Auscultation is not useful for assessing the functioning of an ICD tube.

questions.text: Which of the following would you first advise a patient with a large thyroid swelling on their first visit?
questions.solution:
Assessing the biochemical function of the thyroid i.e. thyroid function test (TFT) is the first investigation done in any thyroid condition.

Evaluation of any thyroid disease should begin with the assessment of TSH, T3, and T4. TSH is the only test necessary in most patients with thyroid nodules that clinically appear to be euthyroid.

Modalities for evaluation of thyroid swelling include:

  • Laboratory evaluation
    • TSH
    • T3
    • T4 
  • Thyroid imaging
    • Ultrasound
    • Radioisotope scanning
    • CT/MRI
  • Biopsy techniques
    • Fine needle aspiration biopsy (FNA)
    • Tru-cut/core-needle biopsy

questions.text: A 31-year-old patient presented to the casualty with severe upper abdominal pain and recurrent retching without vomiting. A nasogastric tube insertion was tried but it was unsuccessful. His X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is most likely related to the above condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and X-ray showing a gas-filled viscus in the upper abdomen is suggestive of gastric volvulus. Most likely related to gastric volvulus is the Borchardt's triad.

Gastric volvulus is the rotation of the gastric fundus occurring on the longitudinal (organoaxial) or vertical (mesenteroaxial) axis of the stomach. This occurs due to the laxity in the peritoneal attachment of the stomach.

The Borchardt triad comprises of:

  • Sudden-onset severe upper abdominal pain
  • Recurrent retching with minimal vomitus
  • Inability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tube

Organoaxial gastric volvulus is a torsion that occurs along the longitudinal axis of the stomach It is the most common type and often occurs acutely. It is associated with a diaphragmatic defect.

Mesenteroaxial gastric volvulus is a torsion that occurs along the vertical axis. It is partial (<180 degrees) and recurrent. It is not associated with a diaphragmatic defect.

Radiograph images shows a gas-filled viscus in the upper abdomen due to rotation of gastric fundus on the axis of the stomach. Gastric volvulus can be confirmed by a barium study. In barium study, the stomach may be inverted with greater curvature above the lesser curvature, or as the pylorus above the cardia. 

Emergency surgery is indicated for acute volvulus which includes decompression, reduction, and prevention of recurrence. The surgical intervention includes simple gastropexy with diaphragmatic hernia repair. 

Other options:

Option B- Dieulafoy’s triad is seen in acute appendicitis. It comprises of hypersensitiveness of skin, reflex muscular contraction, tenderness at Mc Burney’s point.

Option C- Quincke's triad is seen in hemobilia. It comprises upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage, abdominal pain, and obstructive jaundice.

Option D- Saint's triad comprises hiatus hernia, gallstones, and colonic diverticulosis.

questions.text: An AV fistula in the forearm is created in a patient with end-stage renal disease so that he can undergo dialysis. Which of the following responses will you not see when you apply pressure proximal to the AV fistula?
questions.solution:
Pulse pressure returns to normal when pressure is applied to an artery proximal to an AV fistula.

In an AV fistula, peripheral resistance is decreased because of which diastolic pressure is less leading to higher pulse pressure. Compression of the artery proximal to the AV fistula increases peripheral resistance leading to increased diastolic pressure and the pulse pressure returns to normal.

Compression of the artery proximal to an arteriovenous fistula results in:

  • Reflex bradycardia
  • Pulse pressure returns to normal
  • Decrease in size of swelling
  • Bruit will decrease or disappear

The reflex bradycardia and increase in blood pressure that immediately follows the sudden occlusion of an arteriovenous (A-V) fistula is known as the Nicoladoni-Branham sign.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presented with burn injury. He is covered with burns on his head&neck,  both upper limbs, front and back of the chest. Calculate the percentage of burns.
questions.solution:
The percentage of burns calculated in the given patient is 45% according to Wallace’s rule of nine.

Calculation:

  • Burns on the head&neck would account for 9% of burns.
  • Burns on both upper limbs (9% for each limb) would add to 18%  
  • Burns on both sides of the chest would account for 18%

Therefore the total percentage of burns in the given patient is 9+18+18 = 45%
