questions.text: Extramammary Paget's disease is a type of ____
questions.solution:
• Extramammary Paget's disease is a form of intraepidermal adenocarcinoma, which may occur in the genital, perianal regions or in cutaneous sites rich in apocrine glands such as the axilla.
  • Approximately 25% of the cases are associated with an underlying in situ or invasive neoplasm.
  • Surgical excision forms the basis of treatment.

questions.text: A score of 3 for motor response according to the Glasgow Coma Scale indicates _________.
questions.solution:
Motor response of 3 indicates decorticate posture or abnormal flexion to pain stimulus.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild brain injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate brain injury
  • scores ≤8 represent severe brain injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal/flexion 4
Abnormal flexion/Decorticate posturing  3
Extension/Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • The motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils Unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

questions.text: You are asked to perform a quick bedside scoring test to assess the patient's risk of developing sepsis. It utilizes 3 components. Which of the following is not considered as a component while performing this test?
questions.solution:
The bedside scoring test that utilizes 3 components to assess the patient's risk of developing sepsis is the qSOFA (quick sequential organ failure assessment) score. The quick sequential organ failure assessment (qSOFA) scoring system does not rely on the heart rate.

It is a bedside scoring system that identifies patients who are at risk of poor outcomes from sepsis, without reliance upon laboratory or imaging studies. It uses three criteria.

  • Low blood pressure: SBP≤100 mmHg
  • High respiratory rate: ≥22 breaths per min
  • Altered mental status

The qSOFA suggests potentially life-threatening sepsis when at least two of the parameters are met.

The primary method to evaluate the risk of organ dysfunction (sepsis) in patients with suspected infection is by determining the  sequential (sepsis-related) organ failure assessment (SOFA) score; which includes an assessment of:

  • Circulation - Systolic BP & need for vasopressors; platelet count
  • Respiration - PaO2/FiO2 & need for mechanical ventilation
  • Mentation - Glasgow coma score (GCS)
  • Hepatic function - Bilirubin
  • Renal function - Creatinine

Organ dysfunction is identified by a SOFA score of ≥ 2

The SOFA score is limited by its requirement of multiple laboratory tests which makes it complex and time-consuming. In order to simplify the scoring process, the "Sepsis - 3" task force recommended the quick sepsis-related organ dysfunction assessment "qSOFA" score.

questions.text: Identify the pathological finding indicated by the arrow.
questions.solution:
Structures represented by the one marked by the arrow are identified as corpora amylacea.

They are tiny calcified lamellated bodies found in the glandular alveoli of elderly men. 

It is hypothesized that they are the fore-runners of prostatic caliculi.

questions.text: All of the following are lower urinary tract symptoms except

choices.text: Incontinence when patient lies down and coughs

questions.solution:
Incontinence during intercourse is not a lower urinary tract symptom (LUTS). 

The lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS) can be classified as:

Storage LUTS- This occurs due to the failure of the bladder to act as a urine reservoir. It is commonly seen in the overactive bladder or bladder neuropathy. Symptoms related to storage LUTS are:

  • Frequency- Increased frequency of voiding
  • Nocturia- a patient has to wake up at least once at night to void
  • Urgency- the sudden uncontrollable desire to pass urine
  • Urge incontinence- a large volume of involuntary urine leakage preceded by urgency

Voiding LUTS- This is commonly seen in bladder outlet obstruction. Symptoms related to voiding LUTS are:

  • Hesitancy- difficulty in initiating micturition
  • Reduced stream
  • Straining- muscular effort is needed to initiate or to improve the urinary stream

Post micturitional LUTS- This is also caused due to bladder outlet obstruction. Symptoms related to post micturitional LUTS are:

  • Incomplete emptying- a sensation that the bladder is full still remains after micturition
  • Post micturition dribble- Involuntary passage of urine after the patient has finished passing urine.

Other symptoms of LUTS are:

Stress incontinence- dribbling of urine during coughing, laughing, sneezing, or exercising. This occurs in women who have undergone vaginal deliveries.

Nocturnal enuresis- involuntary leakage of urine during sleep. It is commonly seen in elderly men having chronic retention of urine with overflow incontinence.

Strangury- is a sensation of constantly needing to void. Commonly occurs due to a lower urinary tract infection.

questions.text: A 30 years old male presents with continuous discomfort in the right hypochondrium and on examination shows presence of enlarged liver 8cm below the costal margins. The image below shows CT radiograph. The probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The above image shows CT scan of the liver with hydatid cyst seen as a hypodense lesion with internal septation.

Hydatid cysts result from infection by the Echinococcus, and can result in cyst formation anywhere in the body.

Causative agent:

There are two main strains which include:

  1. Echinococcus granulosus: more common
    • pastoral: dog is a main host; most common form
    • sylvatic: wolf is a main host
  2. Echinococcus alveolaris/multilocularis: less common but more invasive; fox is a main host

Investigation:

  • CT examination reveals fluid density cyst, with frequent peripheral focal areas of calcification, usually indicates no active infection if completely circumferential.
  • Septation and daughter cysts may be visualised. The water-lily sign indicates a cyst with floating, undulating membrane, caused by a detached endocyst.
  • May also show hyperdense internal septa representing a spoke wheel pattern within a cyst.

questions.text: The newest drug approved for metastatic hormone receptor–positive and HER-2 negative breast cancer is _____
questions.solution:
Palbociclib is the newest drug approved for metastatic, hormone receptor–positive, HER-2/neu-negative breast cancer.

It is used along with fulvestrant, a selective estrogen-receptor downregulator (SERD) based on the PALOMA 3 trial. 

The US-FDA has recently approved the drug ALPELISIB(PI3K inhibitor)for the treatment of breast cancer in combination with fulvestrant in postmenopausal women

Related Pearl: Newer drugs in chemotherapy for metastatic breast cancer

Treatment of metastatic breast cancer by targeting PI3k/AKT/mTOR pathways has led to newer chemotherapeutic drugs, which are as follows:

Cyclin-dependent kinase 4/6 inhibitor

  • Palbociclib: Approved for use with aromatase inhibitor (Letrozole) or SERD (Fulvestrant)
  • Ribociclib: Approved for use with aromatase inhibitor (Letrozole)
  • Abemaciclib: Approved for use with SERD (Fulvestrant)

mTOR pathway inhibitors

  • Everolimus:  Approved for treatment of advanced/metastatic hormone receptor–positive, HER-2-negative breast cancer

Phophatidyl-inositol 3 kinase (PI3k) inhibitors

  • Buparlisib – Not approved, but trials are underway for treatment of metastatic breast carcinoma

AKT (Protein kinase B) inhibitors

  • Ipatasertib: Not approved, but found beneficial for metastatic triple-negative breast cancer

questions.text: Wilkie's syndrome is associated with which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
Wilkie's syndrome is associated with the superior mesenteric artery.

Wilkie's syndrome, also known as superior mesenteric artery syndrome (SMA), is an acquired disorder in which the third part of the duodenum gets compressed between the superior mesenteric artery anteriorly and the aorta posteriorly, as shown in the image below:


The normal angle between the SMA and aorta ranges from 25-60 degrees, with 45 degrees being the usual angle. A mesenteric fat pad is normally present between the SMA and the third part of the duodenum. In situations of rapid weight loss, abdominal surgery, etc, it is possible to lose this fat pad. This results in a narrowing of the above-mentioned angle. Patients begin to display symptoms when the angle falls below 20 degrees. 

The result is that the third part of the duodenum now gets compressed between these two vessels leading to obstructive symptoms. The common presentation is postprandial abdominal pain with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension. Repeated episodes of vomiting can result in dehydration. 

Diagnosis can be made with a barium meal and follow-through or abdominal CT scan.

The image below shows barium follow through with dilatation of the duodenum and an abrupt cut-off at its third part. The cut-off is coinciding with the expected location of the SMA, depicted by the red line in the x-ray:


The abdominal CT scan with contrast shown below depicts the reduced angle between the SMA and the abdominal aorta shown within the red circle-


This condition is first treated conservatively with gastric decompression, intake of smaller meals, and postural changes like knee-elbow position and left lateral decubitus position. Reversal of the cause such as regaining lost weight can also sometimes show good results. If conservative management fails, the operation of choice is a duodenojejunostomy.

questions.text: All of the following surgeries are done in case of Hirschsprung disease except______.
questions.solution:
• Heineke-Mikulicz operation is a type of pyloroplasty and is not done for Hirschsprung disease.
  • Surgery is the treatment of choice for Hirschsprung disease.
  • A multi-stage approach is adopted, with colostomy in the newborn period, followed by a definitive pull-through operation after the child is over 10 kgs.
  • Definitive surgeries for Hirschsprung disease are as follows:
    • Swenson
    • Duhamel
    • Soave

questions.text: As an intern, you are assessing a 35-year-old woman who was admitted to the emergency department with multiple rib fractures after a road traffic accident. During the examination, you notice paradoxical chest movement, leading to a diagnosis of respiratory failure. Her chest X-ray is shown below. You will manage the patient using all the following methods except?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the X-ray displaying contiguous rib fractures on the right side indicate flail chest, chest strapping or splinting should be avoided in management of flial chest.

Flail Chest :

  • A flail chest occurs when a segment of the chest wall does not have bony continuity with the rest of the thoracic cage.
  • This condition results from blunt trauma associated with multiple rib fractures, i.e. 2 adjacent ribs or 3 or more ribs fractured in two or more places.
  • The blunt force required to disrupt the integrity of the thoracic cage typically produces an underlying pulmonary contusion as well.
  • On inspiration the loose segment of the chest wall is displaced inwards and less air therefore moves into the lungs and on expiration, the segment moves outwards, it is called as paradoxical respiration.

Diagnosis is made clinically, not by radiography. To confirm the diagnosis the chest wall can be observed for paradoxical motion of a chest wall segment for several respiratory cycles and during coughing. Voluntary splinting as a result of pain, mechanically impaired chest wall movement and the associated lung contusion are all causes of the hypoxia and respiratory failure. The patient is also at high risk of developing a pneumothorax or hemothorax.

Treatment :

  • Chest strapping or splinting should be avoided
  • Currently, treatment consists of oxygen administration (Option b ), adequate analgesia (including opiates) or epidural analgesia and physiotherapy (Option d ).
  • IPPV (Intermitent Positive Pressure Ventilation) is reserved for cases developing respiratory failure despite adequate analgesia and oxygen (Option a ).

Treament Algorithm of treatment of flail chest with respiratory failure is given below,

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida at 20 weeks of gestation presents to the OG clinic for targeted sonography.  In the sonogram, a finding of a single umbilical artery is noted.  Which of the following is true regarding the finding?

choices.text: An indicator of increased risk of malformations of the fetus
Equally common in newborns of diabetic and non-diabetic mothers

questions.solution:
Single umbilical artery is the most common aberration of vessel number in the umbilical cord. It is an indicator of increased incidence of congenital malformations in the fetus.  

It is more common in twins and in babies born of women with diabetes, epilepsy, oligohydramnios, hydramnios, pre-eclampsia, and antepartum hemorrhage.

It is frequently associated with congenital malformation of the fetus (20–25%), mainly cardiovascular and genitourinary. Renal and genital anomalies, trisomy 18 are common.

There is an increased chance of abortion, fetal aneuploidy, prematurity, intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), and increased perinatal mortality.

questions.text: All the following increase in Acute fatty liver of pregnancy(AFLP) except
questions.solution:
Platelet count decreases in AFLP, as platelet activation and aggregation is high, which leads to their consumption.

All the other values such as creatinine, d-dimer, prothrombin timeand clotting time increase.

questions.text: Which of the following regarding sensitivity of uterine musculature is true?

choices.text: Enhanced by both estrogen and progesterone
Enhanced by estrogen and inhibited by progesterone

questions.solution:
Sensitivity of uterine musculature is enhanced by estrogen and inhibited by progesterone.

Estrogen stimulates the synthesis of myometrial contractile protein through cAMP.The uterine muscles become more active and excitable and action potentials become more frequent.

Progesterone decreases the frequency and intensity of uterine contractions, thereby helping to prevent the expulsion of the implanted ovum but increases the amplitude of contraction.

questions.text: Radiotherapy is indicated in vulval cancer stage
questions.solution: • Radiotherapy is indicated in stage 1 node +ve, 2 node +ve, 3 & 4

questions.text: The partogram is plotted in regular intervals after _ cm dilatation:
questions.solution:
The partograph is plotted in regular intervals after 4 cm dilatation.

In a partograph, the labor process is divided into

  1. Latent phase ends when cervix dilated upto 4 cm
  2. Active phase begins with cervical dilatation of ≥6 cm and ends at 10 cm dilatation at the rate of 1 cm/hour.

The latent phase of labour is slow and extremely variable, while the active phase of labour is fairly predictable in terms of duration. Even though the active phase of labor is from more than 6cm dilatation, partograph is marked from 4 cm dilatation.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida delivered a baby at term with a birth weight of 2.5 kg via normal vaginal delivery. The placenta delivered appears as shown in the image below. Which of the following complications is less likely to be associated with this placental variant?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a bilobed placenta also known as placenta bilobate or bipartite placenta or placenta duplex. Fetal growth restriction is not a complication likely to be associated with this placental variant.

A bilobed placenta is described as the presence of two, almost equally sized placental lobes separated by a membrane, without significant vasculature present in between them. The umbilical cord may be inserted between the two placental lobes into the chorionic bridge, or into the intervening membranes, or in a velamentous fashion. The presence of more than two lobes is termed as multilobate placenta and is rare.

The complications associated with this placental variant are:

  • First-trimester bleeding
  • Polyhydramnios
  • Abruption
  • Retained placenta

The types of placental variants are:

  • Placenta succenturiata: One or more unequally sized smaller placental lobes at distant sites from the bulk of the placenta. Vessels are present in the intervening membranes that connect the two lobes.   
  • Placenta membranacea: Unduly large and thin placenta that develops from both the chorionic frondosum and the chorion leave.  
  • Ring-shaped placenta: This is a variant of placenta membranacea where a partial or complete ring of the placenta is present.  
  • Placenta fenestrata: In this, the central portion of a placental disc is missing.
  • Battledore placenta: In this, the umbilical cord is inserted at or near the placental margin rather than at the center.  
  • Extrachorial placentation: the chorionic plate is smaller than the basal plate. There are two types of extrachorial placentation:
    • Circummarginate placenta - In this type, the space between the fetal membranes and the basal plate is filled up by fibrin and old hemorrhage with a smooth margin.
    • Circumvallate placenta - In this type, the peripheral chorion is thickened into a ridge composed of a double fold of chorion and amnion.

questions.text:
An anxious primigravida came to you for a second opinion with the report of a second-trimester scan and biochemical screening test suspecting Down syndrome. Which of the following are suggestive of Down syndrome?
  1. Hypoplasia of nasal bone
  2. Elevated levels of unconjugated estriol
  3. Sandal gap between first and second toes
  4. Reduced levels of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP)
  5. Low levels of beta HCG
questions.solution:
Hypoplasia of nasal bone, sandal gap between first and second toes, and reduced levels of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (1, 3, and 4) are sonographic and biochemical features suggestive of Down's syndrome or Trisomy 21.

Soft signs or second-trimester sonographic markers associated with Down syndrome fetuses are:

  • Brachycephaly or shortened frontal lobe
  • Clinodactyly (hypoplasia of the 5th digit middle phalanx)
  • Flat facies
  • Echogenic bowel, echogenic intracardiac focus
  • Absence or hypoplasia of the nasal bone
  • Nuchal fold thickening
  • Sandal gap between first and second toes
  • Single transverse palmar crease
  • Single umbilical artery

A focal papillary muscle calcification that is neither a structural nor functional cardiac abnormality is called an echogenic intracardiac focus. Echogenic fetal bowel which appears as bright as the bone has a six-fold increased risk for Down syndrome. 

 

The abnormalities seen on the quadruple screening test for Down syndrome are:

 Biochemical screening test

Down syndrome

(Trisomy 21)
MSAFP Low
Unconjugated estriol Low
β hCG High 
Inhibin A High

questions.text: Which of the following need not be performed in a patient with recurrent pregnancy loss?
questions.solution:
Most patients with a history of recurrent pregnancy loss do not benefit from an extensive infection work-up, as no infectious agent has been proven to cause recurrent pregnancy loss.

Suggested Diagnostic Evaluation of Recurrent Pregnancy Loss Based on Etiology

Etiology  Suggested Diagnostic Evaluation 
Genetic  Parental karyotype 
Anatomic  HSG or office hysteroscopy 2D or 3D ultrasound Saline-infusion sonohysterography 
Endocrine 

TSH

Testing for insulin resistance

Serum prolactin level

Ovarian reserve testing

Antithyroid antibodies 
Infectious  No evaluation recommended unless the patient has evidence of chronic endometritis/cervicitis on examination, or is immunocompromised 
Autoimmune 

Anticardiolipin antibody levels (IgG and IgM) 

Lupus anticoagulant   

Homocysteine

Factor V Leiden

Prothrombin promoter mutation

Activated protein C resistance

questions.text: A 35-year-old with molar pregnancy detected on USG has multiple theca lutein cysts presenting with torsion of the cyst. Management would be ____

choices.text: Wait and watch as the cysts regress on their own after treatment of molar pregnancy

questions.solution:
Untwisting of the cyst is the only management in an asymptomatic patient with a twisted theca lutein cyst.

Laparoscopic oophorectomy is done only when there is associated extensive necrosis or hemorrhage.

Theca-lutein cysts regress within 2 months after pregnancy evacuation, and hence expectant management is preferred in uncomplicated cases. If the cysts are symptomatic, they can be aspirated trans-abdominally under ultrasound guidance.

questions.text: A lady at 14 weeks of gestation presents with abdominal pain and persistent browny vaginal discharge for a few days. On examination, the uterus appears smaller than the period of gestation with a closed cervical os. Doppler ultrasound reveals non-audibility of the fetal heart sound which was audible before. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a woman with 14 weeks of gestation presenting with abdominal pain, persistent browny vaginal discharge, smaller uterus for gestation, closed cervical os, non-audibility of the fetal heart sound in ultrasound is suggestive of missed miscarriage.

Missed miscarriage or early fetal demise is termed when the fetus is dead and retained inside the uterus for a variable period.

Patients usually present with features of threatened miscarriage like dull pain or bleeding per vaginum followed by:

  • Persistence of brownish vaginal discharge
  • Subsidence of pregnancy symptoms
  • Retrogression of breast changes
  • The uterus appears smaller in size (cessation of uterine growth)
  • Nonaudibility of the fetal heart sound
  • Closed cervical os
  • Cervix feels firm
  • Negative immunological test for pregnancy
  • Empty sac in real-time ultrasonography

Beyond 12 weeks, the retained fetus in the uterus becomes macerated and mummified. 

The expulsion or extraction from the mother of an embryo or fetus weighing 500 g or less when it is not capable of independent survival is termed abortion.

Classification of abortion:

Other options:

Option A- Inevitable miscarriage is the type of abortion where continuation of pregnancy is impossible.

Features:

  • Increased vaginal bleeding
  • Aggravation of pain in the lower abdomen which may be colicky in nature
  • Dilated internal os
  • Rupture of the membranes

Option C- Threatened miscarriage is the type of abortion where the process of miscarriage has started but in a state from which recovery is possible. 

Features:

  • Bleeding which is usually slight and may be brownish or bright red in color
  • Usually painless but pain appears following hemorrhage
  • Closed external os
  • Uterine size corresponds to the period of amenorrhea
  • The uterus and cervix feel soft
  • On ultrasound:
    • Well-formed gestation ring
    • Presence of fetal cardiac motion 

Option D- Complete miscarriage is termed when products of conception are expelled en masse.

Features:

  • Abdominal pain subsides
  • Decreased or absent vaginal bleeding
  • The uterus is smaller than the period of amenorrhea
  • The cervical os is closed
  • Examination of the expelled fleshy mass is found complete.
  • Ultrasound shows an empty uterine cavity

questions.text:
Which of the following are implicated in the pathogenesis of gestational diabetes mellitus?
  1. Free cortisol
  2. Estrogen
  3. Progesterone
  4. Human Placental Lactogen
  5. Human Chorionic Gonadotropin
questions.solution:
Free cortisol, estrogen, progesterone, and Human Placental Lactogen (HPL) are implicated in the pathogenesis of gestational diabetes mellitus.

Gestational diabetes mellitus occurs due to the combined insulin-antagonistic effects of HPL, estrogen, progesterone, free cortisol, and also due to the degradation of the insulin by the placenta. As the pregnancy advances, insulin demand also increases due to these hormonal changes.

questions.text: A 26-year-old G3P2 with Rh-negative status presents to the OG clinic with an antibody titer of 1:16 in ICT at 28 weeks of gestation. An ultrasound was done to screen for hydrops fetalis. What is the earliest sign to be seen in USG?
questions.solution:
Earliest sign of hydrops fetalis in USG is scalp edema / Subcutaneous edema also know as Halo sign. 

Other USG signs include:

  • Ascites
  • Pleural effusion 
  • Pericardial effusion  
  • Typical position termed as Buddha's position

questions.text: Identify the maternal condition that can lead to the findings in the baby as shown below.
questions.solution:
The image showing a poorly developed lower limb suggests the diagnosis of caudal regression sequence/sacral agenesis seen in pregestational diabetes. It is the most specific anomaly seen in diabetes. 

Gastrulation is the process that forms all the 3 germ layers namely, ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm in the embryo. It occurs during the 3rd week of gestation. In cases of caudal dysgenesis, also known as sirenomelia, there is a lack of mesoderm formation in the most caudal region of the embryo. Abnormalities occur in the lower limbs, urogenital system (intermediate mesoderm), and lumbosacral vertebrae due to the contribution of the mesoderm to their creation. Individuals affected with this condition have a diverse array of abnormalities, such as underdevelopment and merging of the lower limbs, defects in the vertebrae, absence of the kidneys, an imperforate anus, and abnormalities in the genital system.

The caudal regression sequence is a rare malformation, frequently associated with maternal pre-gestational diabetes. It consists of a spectrum of structural defects of the caudal region, including incomplete development of the sacrum and the lumbar vertebrae.

Elevated maternal HbA1c levels correlate with fetal malformations. It occurs approximately 200 times more frequently in infants of diabetic mothers than in other infants. 

Overt diabetes (pregestational diabetes) is associated with higher malformation rates than the general population. Neural tube defects (encephalocele, meningomyelocele, anencephaly), transposition of great vessels, ventricular septal defect, atrial septal defect, hypoplastic left heart, aortic stenosis and coarctation of the aorta are commonly seen. Small left colon syndrome is a rare anomaly that develops in the second and third trimesters.

Other options:

Option B: Malformations are not associated with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). Malformations occur due to the disruption of organogenesis, usually occurring in the first trimester. The abnormal glycemic status in GDM manifests only in the second trimester. 

Option C: Valproate leads to neural tube defects and not sacral agenesis.

Option D: ACE inhibitors can cause oligohydramnios.

questions.text: Billing’s method for contraception refers to _________
questions.solution:
Billing’s method for contraception refers to cervical mucus method.

Mucus method (billings or ovulation method):

  • Under oestrogen influence, the mucus increases in quantity and becomes progressively more slippery and elastic until a peak is reached. Thereafter, the mucus becomes thicker, scanty and dry under the influence of progesterone until the onset of menses. Intercourse is considered safe during the ‘dry days’ immediately after the menses until mucus is detected. Thereafter, the couple must abstain until the fourth day after the ‘peak day’.

Mucus secretion during a menstrual cycle:

questions.text: A multiparous woman has a previous history of birth trauma with injury to the uterosacral and cardinal ligaments. According to De Lancey's classification, which level of uterine support is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
According to DeLancey's classification, level 1 of uterine support is affected in this patient as the uterosacral and cardinal ligaments are injured.

DeLancey introduced three-level systems of genital tract supports:

  • Level I includes uterosacral and cardinal ligaments. Damage to these ligaments leads to uterine descent, enterocoele, and vault prolapse.
  • Level II includes pelvic fascia, paracolpos,arcus tendineus, pubocervical, and rectovaginal fascia. Damage to these structures leads to cystocele and rectocele.
  • Level III includes levator ani muscle and its damage leads to urethrocele, gaping introitus, and deficient perineum.

questions.text: As a senior resident in the OBG department, You would consider the following procedure as a treatment option in all of the following cases except

choices.text: Removal of placenta accreta in multiparous woman

questions.solution:
The procedure shown in the above image is uterine artery embolization (UAE). It is indicated in all the above-given cases except in a patient with calcified fibroids.

Uterine artery embolization is an angiographic procedure where polyvinyl alcohol microspheres are introduced into both uterine arteries, producing ischemia and necrosis of the fibroid. This technique is used preoperatively to reduce vascularity and thereby to reduce the size of the fibroid. It is best suited to control symptoms of pressure and menorrhagia in multiparous women.

A calcified fibroid does not shrink with the procedure. Pedunculated fibroids can fall off after the procedure resulting in intrauterine or peritoneal infections.

Hence, the calcified, submucous, and subserous types of fibroids are contraindications for this procedure. 

Other indications for uterine artery embolization include,

  • Postpartum hemorrhage.
  • Placenta accreta to reduce bleeding prior to placental removal, or caesarean delivery.
  • This technique is most suited for menorrhagia in a multiparous woman

Technique:

  • Under local sedation, bilateral UAE is ap­proached through percutaneous femoral catheterization.
  • It is done using polyvinyl alcohol (PVA), gel foam particles or metal coils.

Embolization reduces vascularity and the size of the fibroid in 3–4 months

Advantages of UAE:

  • No major surgery.
  • No intraoperative bleeding.
  • Short hospital stay.
  • Less abdominal adhesions.

questions.text: Amsel’s criteria for diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis include all except _______
questions.solution:
Abundant polymorphs is not included in Amsel’s criteria.

Amsel’s criteria is used for diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis which includes

  • Homogenous vaginal discharge
  • Vaginal pH > 4.5
  • Amine like odour on adding KOH (Whiff test positive)
  • Clue cells (>20% of cells)

Polymorphs are few as there is no inflammation.

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

  Bacterial vaginosis Trichomonas vaginalis

Candida albicans
Causative organism  Altered vaginal flora- increased concentration of Gardnerella vaginalis Trichomas vaginalis-parasitic infection Fungal infection
Etiology Increased vaginal pH Sexually transmitted Decreased immunity
Sexual trans-mission No Yes No

Symptoms Fishy odor, no itching Itching and burning Itching, burning
pH >4.5 >4.5 <4.5
Speculum No vaginal epithelium inflammation Strawberry cervix Inflamed-epithelium
KOH Positive Whiff test Whiff test can be positive. Pseudohyphae seen.
Wet mount Clue cells. No WBCs seen Motile trichomaonads, WBCs seen WBCs seen
Treatment Metronidazole or Clindamycin Metronidazole, treat partner also Oral or vaginal azole, no need to treat partner.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient presented malodorous discharge in the vagina. Whiff's test was positive and a Pap smear is performed. The microscopy of the discharge is shown below.  Which of the following drugs is most effective in treating her condition?
questions.solution: The given image shows clue cells that are seen in bacterial vaginosis caused by Gardnerella. They are vaginal epithelial cells with their surface covered by adherent bacilli. Treatment is oral metronidazole 500 mg BD for 7 days. Alternatively, ampicillin 500 mg or cephalosporin 500 mg bid for 7 days is also effective.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman is being evaluated for bleeding per vagina. She attained menopause at the age of 47. Which of the following is least likely to be a cause of post-menopausal bleeding?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Ovarian Follicular cysts are least likely to be a cause of post-menopausal bleeding. They are usually asymptomatic unless they rupture, hemorrhage or the ovary undergoes torsion which would manifest as an acute abdomen. They occur when there is the failure of absorption of fluid in an incompletely developed follicle or anovulation. 

Postmenopausal bleeding is diagnosed when there is bleeding per vagina after 6 months of amenorrhoea after the age of 40 (menopausal age). 

Causes of postmenopausal bleeding include: 

  • Genital tract trauma (Option A)
  • Cervical erosion, inflammation, polyp, or ulcer
  • Uterus - endometritis, endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial carcinoma (Option C), polyp, or sarcoma
  • Fallopian tube malignancy
  • Ovarian tumors such as Brenner tumor, granulosa cell tumor (Option D)
  • Hypertension and blood dyscrasia
  • Urinary tract trauma, bladder carcinoma
  • Hemorrhoid, anal fissures, and rectal cancers confused as bleeding per vagina
  • Use of estrogens as hormone replacement therapy, tamoxifen.

The image below gives a summary of the evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding, as per the FOGSI guidelines.

questions.text: A couple presented to the infertility clinic with complaints of inability to conceive for 2 years. As a part of the evaluation, semen analysis was done. The leukocyte level should be approximately__
questions.solution:
The normal leucocyte level in human semen is approximately 1 million/ml.

The semen sample should be collected after two to seven days ejaculatory abstinence. If possible, the patient should collect the sample by masturbation at the doctor's office. If not possible, then the sample may be collected at home and delivered to the laboratory within an hour of collection.

Hypospermia - Volume less than 1.5 mL. 

Hyperspermia - More than 5.5 mL - due to prolonged abstinence or inflammation of seminal vesicle.

Concentration below 15 million/mL - Suggestive of infertility, though counts 20 million/mL or more is desirable.

Mild oligospermia : 10–15 million/mL 

Moderate oligospermia : 5–10 million/mL 

Severe oligospermia : less than 5 million/mL

questions.text: Which among the following is the treatment of choice when micro invasion is suspected in cervical neoplasia?
questions.solution:
Conization is the preferred treatment modality when microinvasion is suspected in a patient.

Cone biopsy involves a wide cone excision that includes the entire outer margin of the lesion and the entire endocervical lining, by using the cold-knife technique under general anesthesia. Disadvantages include bleeding, infection, cervical stenosis, and cervical incompetence

Hysterectomy is done when microinvasion is confirmed.

  • Indications of conization
    • Endocervical dysplasia
    • The transformation zone is not completely visualized
    • When there is discrepancy of findings between cytolology, colposcopy & biopsy
    • Microinvasion is suspected
  • Indications of hysterectomy
    • Older & parous women
    • Uterus is suspected with fibroid, DUB, prolapsed
    • Microinvasion exists
    • Recurrence or persistent lesion
    • In – situ adenocarcinoma cervix

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

WHO grade CIN grade Description Bethesda  Treatment
Mild Dysplasia CIN I Dysplastic cells in lower 1/3 of cervix LSIL Colposcopic directed biopsy
Moderate Dysplasia CIN II Dysplastic cells up to 2/3 of cervix HSIL Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage
Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of cervix HSIL Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage
Carcinoma in situ Carcinoma in situ Dysplastic cells in full thickness but basement membrane is intact HSIL  Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage

Abbreviations:

CIN: Cervical Intra-epithelial neoplasia

LSIL: Low Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

HSIL: High Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

questions.text: Triad of Gregg in a fetus is seen in congenital infection with ____
questions.solution:
Triad of Gregg is seen in a neonate infected congenitally with Rubella virus. The features include:

  • Patent ductus arteriosus(PDA)
  • Cataract
  • Sensorineural Hearing loss(SNHL)

Other infections which cause congenital malformations are:

Organism Effect
Toxoplasma

Hydro/Microcephaly,Convulsions,

Chorioretinitis, Cerebral calcification
Rubella PDA, Cataract, SNHL
Varicella

Skin scarring, Hypoplastic limbs,

Eye defects, Microcephaly
Parvovirus Non immune hydrops
Syphyllis

Bone defect hydrops

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman presented with complaints of dull pain over the right lower abdomen for the past 2  months. CT scan revealed a left-sided multiloculated adnexal mass and exploratory laparotomy showed the following mass. Which of the following is incorrect regarding the condition?

choices.text: They are the most common epithelial tumors

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the gross image are suggestive of mucinous cystadenoma. Serous cystadenoma is the most common epithelial tumor not mucinous.

Mucinous cystadenomas are mostly benign. They are usually present during the third to sixth decade of life and the majority of them are unilateral.

They are usually multilocular, thick-walled, and have a smooth surface. Histology shows multiple cysts and glands liner by simple non-stratified mucinous epithelium. The epithelium resembles gastric foveolar type or intestinal epithelium containing goblet cells. 

Complications of mucinous cystadenoma of the ovary include torsion, spontaneous rupture, pseudomyxoma peritonei, and secondary malignancies.

In pseudomyxoma peritonei, the peritoneal cavity is filled with coagulated mucinous martial adherent to the omentum and intestines.  

Below image shows serous cystadenoma

questions.text: In a pregnancy with increased Maternal Serum Alpha Feto Protein (MSAFP),  which is the next step of management?

choices.text: Repeat measurement of MSAFP at a later date

questions.solution:
MSAFP is a screening test. If it is raised, should be followed by a diagnostic test and the most preferred test is targeted sonography.

Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)

  • It is the major serum protein in the embryo and fetus.
  • It's concentration increases steadily in both fetal serum and amnionic fluid until 13 weeks gestation, after which, levels rapidly decline. Conversely, AFP is found in steadily increasing quantities in maternal serum after 12 weeks.
  • Defects in fetal integument, such as neural-tube and ventral wall defects, permit AFP to leak into the amnionic fluid, resulting in dramatically increased maternal serum AFP levels.
  • Maternal serum AFP screening is generally performed from 15 through 20 weeks.

Note : Amniocentesis is a diagnostic test for amniotic fluid AFP measurement. It was once considered the standard for the diagnosis of open neural tube disorders, and now it has been replaced in most centers by targeted sonography.

questions.text: Pressure of normal uterine contractions is between 190-300 units. What is the unit being referred to here?
questions.solution:
The concept of Montevideo units defines uterine activity.

Uterine performance is the product of intensity which is the increased uterine pressure above the baseline tone of a contraction in mm of Hg multiplied by contraction frequency per 10 minutes.

For e.g: if 3 contractions occur in 10 minutes, each of 50 mm of Hg, this would equal 150 Montevideo units.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown below.
questions.solution:
The shown forceps have no catch and have fenestrated blades suggestive of ovum forceps.

Ovum forceps are used to remove the products of conception in dilation and evacuation without crushing the conceptus. Other uses are:

  • Removal of molar tissue from hydatidiform mole
  • Removal of small uterine polyp

Uterine wall injuries are minimal due to the absence of catch. It is introduced with the blades closed and then opened up inside the uterine cavity to grasp the products. The instrument is taken out with a slight rotatory movement. The rotatory movement facilitates the detachment of the products from the uterine wall and also minimizes the injury of the uterine wall if accidentally grasped.

The following image shows the ovum forceps. 

Other options:

Option A- Sponge holding forceps is used to:

  • Clean skin with a swab dipped in antiseptic solution during any abdominal or vaginal operations
  • Toilet vulva, vagina, and perineum prior to and following delivery
  • Hold the membranes if it threatens to tear during delivery of the placenta
  • Hold the cervix during cerclage procedures

The following image shows the sponge holding forceps. 

Option C- Lane's tissue forceps are used to:

  • Hold parietal wall for retraction during abdominal operations with transverse incision (hysterectomy)
  • Hold the polyp or fibroid in polypectomy or myomectomy surgery
  • Hold towel during draping

The following image shows Lane's tissue forceps. 

Option D- Allis tissue forceps are used to:

  • Catch the anterior lip of the cervix in a dilation and evacuation procedure
  • Hold the apex of the episiotomy wound during repair
  • Catch hold margins of the peritoneum, rectus sheath, vaginal mucosa during repair
  • Catch hold the torn ends of the external sphincter ani prior to suture repair of complete perineal tear

The following image shows Allis tissue forceps.

questions.text: Which of the following is not the mechanism of action of progesterone only pills?

choices.text: Kill the sperms when they enter the cervical canal

questions.solution:
Progesterone only pills do not kill sperms.

The mechanisms of action of Progesterone only pills are:

  • Thickening of the cervical mucus that inhibits penetration of sperms (mainly) and
  • Inhibition of ovulation

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman visits an infertility clinic for evaluation of ovulation function on day 21 of her 28-day menstrual cycle. Which of the following would indicate that ovulation has occurred?

LH- Luteinizing hormone

BBT- Basal body temperature
questions.solution:
Among the given options, a biphasic pattern of basal body temperature would indicate that ovulation has occurred.

Tests for ovulation

  • The basal body temperature decreases during ovulation and then increases by 1/2 to 1°F during the progestational half of the cycle. It is seen as a biphasic pattern when plotted on a chart. This is due to the thermogenic action of the progesterone. However, this method cannot accurately predict ovulation. It provides a retrospective diagnosis of ovulation and is not useful therapeutically. It is shown in the image below.
  • The progesterone levels above 4-6ng/mL on day 21 (in a 28-day cycle) confirm if ovulation has occurred. The corpus luteum is the major source of progesterone and is formed only if a woman ovulates.
  • Detection of LH surge (increase in LH) is used to predict the time of ovulation. LH surge occurs 24 hours prior to ovulation. It is detected by daily monitoring of LH levels, hence urinary LH monitoring is much more convenient as compared to serum LH monitoring.
  • Fern test- Appearance of a fern pattern is seen before ovulation. After ovulation, the progesterone thickens the cervical mucus leading to the loss of fern pattern. 

Positive fern test as seen before ovulation is shown in the image below.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding the sterilization device used in the image shown below?
  1. Has a failure rate of 40%
  2. Blocks the fallopian tube permanently
  3. Needs temporary contraception post insertion for 3 months
  4. Can be done only under general anesthesia
questions.solution:
The above image shows the hysteroscopic insertion of Essure into the fallopian tube. Only statements 2 and 3 are correct.

The Essure permanent device is the latest method of hysteroscopic sterilization. It is a dynamically expanding micro-inserter consisting of a flexible inner coil made of stainless steel and a dynamic outer coil made of nickel-titanium alloy (nitinol).

The scar tissue grows into the device and blocks the fallopian tube permanently. It is an irreversible technique and a hysterosalpingogram (HSG) is performed after 3 months of insertion to ensure the proper placement and total occlusion. A success rate of 99.74% is seen with the Essure device. 

Disadvantages:

  • Requires hysteroscopy 
  • Need expertise and costly
  • Permanent method
  • Hysterosalpingogram required to confirm blockage
  • 3 months waiting period and needs temporary contraception
  • Bilateral insertion is difficult due to spasms in 15% of cases
  • Tuboplasty for reversal is not possible
  • Perforation of the tube

Advantage:

  • No abdominal scar and can be done under local anesthesia

questions.text: The number of fontanelles present in a newborn child is _______.
questions.solution:
The number of fontanelles present in a newborn child is six.

Fontanels are the fibrous, membrane-covered gaps created when more than two cranial bones are juxtaposed, as opposed to sutures, which are narrow seams of fibrous connective tissue that separate the flat bones of the skull.

  • The diameter of the anterior fontanelle ranges from 0.6 cm to 3.6 cm, with a mean of 2.1 cm; it closes by 18- 24 months of age
  • At birth, the average size of the posterior fontanel is 0.5-0.7 cm. The fontanel usually is completely closed by 2-3 months of age.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT seen as a result of maternal use of methadone during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Congenital anomalies are not seen as a result of methadone use in pregnancy.

Use of opioids and its derivatives during pregnancy results in opioid withdrawal in the newborn called neonatal abstinence syndrome.

The features of neonatal abstinence syndrome include:

  • Development of withdrawal signs during the 1st week of life
  • Tremors and hyperirritability - most prominent features
  • Hyperreflexia and hypertonia
  • Irritability and wakefulness
  • Poor feeding, diarrhea, and vomiting
  • High pitched cry and fist sucking
  • Setting sun sign

Management includes care in a quiet setting with reduced external stimuli. Opiate replacement with methadone or buprenorphine (oral/sublingual) is the pharmacological treatment for heroin and methadone withdrawal.

questions.text:
An ASHA worker attends her second visit for a 3-day-old newborn delivered at home. She noticed multiple pustular lesions sparing palms and soles as shown below and referred to you. What is the next line of management?

ASHA - Accredited social health activist
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and an image showing yellow-white papules or pustules with surrounding erythematous flare are suggestive of erythema toxicum. They do not require any treatment.

Erythema toxicum is a benign transient dermatological lesion that resolves spontaneously without any treatment. 

Erythema toxicum occurs in one-half of all full-term infants and less commonly in preterm infants. Lesions are firm yellow-white to white 1- 2 mm papules or pustules. They are surrounded by erythematous flare. The lesions are sparse or numerous and either clustered or widely spread over much of the body surface with sparing of palms and soles.

Most of the lesion occurs in 1- 3 days of life and persists for 1 week. Generally, they resolve without pigmentation.

Eosinophils can be demonstrated on intralesional contents and cultures are usually sterile.

questions.text: A child is brought to a pediatrician for a regular check-up. He observed that the child could run stiffly, crawl up or downstairs, pull a wheeled toy along the floor, scribble and build a tower of 3 blocks. What could be the possible age of the child?
questions.solution:
The child is possibly 18 months old.

At age 18 months, the child the milestones attained by the child are:

  • Motor:
    • Run
    • Crawl up and downstairs
    • Explore drawers and wastebasket
  • Adaptive:
    • Make a tower of 3-4 blocks
    • Can scribble
  • Language:
    • Name pictures
    • Identify 1 or more parts of the body
    • A vocabulary of around 10 words
  • Social:
    • Feed themselves
    • Seek help when in trouble
    • May complain when wet or soiled

Other options:

Option B- At 24 months of age, the child can run well, walk up and down the stairs one step at a time, jump. He would be able to build a tower of 6-7 cubes and make circular strokes. He can make 3-word sentences. 

Option C- At 12 months, the child walks with one hand held, has a mature pincer grasp, and can say a few words besides "mama" and "dada." He may be able to play a simple ball game.

Option D- At 30 months, the child can climb stairs with alternating feet, and build a tower of 9 cubes. He can copy a circle. He knows his full name, and refers to himself as "I".

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids, present in breast milk in large amounts, helps in brain development ?
questions.solution:
Taurine present in breastmilk helps in brain development.

Taurine is one of the most abundant amino acids present in breast milk. Levels of taurine are high in the brain and eye (retina) of a newborn (almost twice as that found in adults). 

Other functions of taurine include conjugation of bile acids and osmoregulation.

questions.text: The following feature is not seen in:
questions.solution:
Simian crease (single transverse palmar crease) is not seen in cystic fibrosis. 

Simian crease is seen in:

  • Down's syndrome
  • Fetal alcohol syndrome
  • Trisomy 13
  • Cri du chat syndrome

questions.text: Accumulation of ______ takes place in Farber’s disease.
questions.solution:
Accumulation of Ceramide is seen in Farber’s disease due to ceramidase deficiency.

 Clinical features of Farber’s disease :

  • Painful joint swelling, nodules, progressive joint deformity
  • Hoarse cry
  • Breathing difficulty
  • Failure to thrive

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Polio Endgame Strategy 2019-2023 by WHO?

choices.text: Stop all circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV) outbreaks within 120 days of detection
Separation of polio surveillance and vaccine preventable disease surveillance
Interrupt transmission of all wild poliovirus (WPV)

questions.solution:
Integration, not separation, of polio surveillance with vaccine-preventable disease (VPD) surveillance, is a part of Polio Endgame Strategy 2019-2023.

Goals of the Polio Endgame Strategy 2019–2023

Goal One: Eradication

  • Interrupt transmission of all wild poliovirus (WPV)
  • Stop all circulating vaccine-derived poliovirus (cVDPV) outbreaks within 120 days of detection and eliminate the risk of emergence of future VDPVs

Goal two: Integration

  • Contribute to strengthening immunization and health systems to help achieve and sustain polio eradication
  • Ensure sensitive poliovirus surveillance through integration with comprehensive vaccine-preventable disease (VPD) and communicable disease surveillance systems
  • Prepare for and respond to future outbreaks and emergencies

Goal Three: Certification & Containment

  • Certify eradication of WPV
  • Contain all polioviruses

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents to the emergency department after accidental ingestion of a household cleaning agent containing alkali. Which of the following could be done as the first step in treatment?

choices.text: Gag the child to induce emesis

questions.solution:
The recommended first step in the case of alkali ingestion is dilution through the administration of milk or water.

Contraindications in a case of caustic (strong acid or alkali) ingestion:

  • Neutralization
  • Induced emesis
  • Gastric lavage

questions.text: A newborn developed tachypnea and grunting immediately after birth. On examination, the baby was cyanotic with a scaphoid abdomen. A chest radiograph was taken which is as shown below. Which of the following should be avoided in the management of this baby?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the X-ray showing herniation of the bowel loops into the chest and absence of bowel loops in the abdomen are suggestive of congenital diaphragmatic hernia. Bag and mask ventilation is to be avoided in the management of this baby.

Congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH) is a birth defect of the diaphragm. Malformation of the diaphragm allows the abdominal organs to push into the chest cavity, hindering proper lung formation and resulting in pulmonary hypoplasia. The most common type of CDH is a Bochdalek hernia and in most cases involving the left side. CDH is a life-threatening pathology in infants and a major cause of morbidity and mortality due to two complications: pulmonary hypoplasia and pulmonary hypertension.

Treatment:

The immediate step in the management is the naso- or orogastric tube placement for decompression. The airway is to be secured with endotracheal intubation (option B) and respiratory distress is stabilised. Bag and mask ventilation may increase the abdominal distension and limit the expansion of the hypoplastic lungs. Hence, bag and mask ventilation should be avoided.

Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) (option A) and high-frequency oscillatory ventilation (Option D) have been used as a part of the ventilation strategy to support respiratory failure. The main goal is to maintain oxygenation to the lungs and carbon dioxide washout without causing volutrauma.

Surgical repair of the defect is to be considered at least 48 hours after stabilization and resolution of pulmonary hypertension.

questions.text: Anatomical closure of ductus arteriosus occurs at_________.
questions.solution: Ductus arteriosus is functionally closed at 10-15 hrs after birth and then anatomical closure occurs at 10-21 days.

questions.text: A child presents with generalised edema and was found to have hypercholesterolemia. Urine analysis shows protein 3+ and fat bodies. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario showing a child with generalized edema, hyperlipidemia, massive proteinuria, and fat bodies is highly suggestive of nephrotic syndrome.

Glomerular diseases associated with heavy proteinuria clinically manifests as Nephrotic Syndrome.

The triad of clinical findings associated with nephrotic syndrome :

  • Hypoalbuminemia (≤2.5 g/dL)
  • Edema
  • Hyperlipidemia (cholesterol >200 mg/dL)

along with proteinuria > 3.5 g/24 hr or a urine protein:creatinine ratio >2 to warrant a diagnosis of nephrotic syndrome.

Causes of nephrotic syndrome :

Primary/Idiopathic - 

  • Minimal change disease (most common)
  • Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis
  • Membranous nephropathy
  • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
  • Crescentic glomerulonephritis

Secondary to diseases such as :

  • Systemic lupus erythematosus,
  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura,
  • Malignancies (lymphoma and leukemia)
  • Infections (hepatitis, HIV, and malaria)

Other options :

Nephritic syndrome classically presents with tea- or cola-colored urine (hematuria), edema, hypertension, and oliguria.

Conditions which present as glomerulonephritis:

  • Postinfectious glomerulonephritis
  • IgA nephropathy (Option D)
  • Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
  • Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) nephritis
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) nephritis
  • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
  • Goodpasture syndrome (Option C)
  • Hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS)

questions.text: The given appearance of the skull is classically seen in
questions.solution:
The given X ray skull shows tramline calcifications within the cortices classical of Sturge Weber syndrome.

Sturge–Weber syndrome

It is a congenital neurocutaneous syndrome characterized by a port-wine naevus on the face and ipsilateral leptomeningeal angiomas with a primarily parieto-occipital distribution.

MRI features :

  • The involved hemisphere progressively becomes atrophied
  • Other findings include enlargement of the ipsilateral choroid plexus and dilatation of transparenchymal veins that communicate between the superficial and deep cerebral venous systems.

Classical port-wine naevus in Sturge-Weber syndrome

questions.text: The image given below depicts an x-ray of the knee in a term baby. Which among the following conditions is associated with it?
questions.solution:
The deformity shown in the X-ray image is the absence of distal femoral epiphysis, which is a typical radiological feature of congenital hypothyroidism.

X-ray findings in hypothyroidism

  • Absence of distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphyses at birth.
  • Punctate epiphyseal dysgenesis (multiple foci of ossification)
  • Deformity or beaking of the 12th thoracic or 1st or 2nd lumbar vertebra
  • X-ray image of the skull shows large fontanels and wide sutures; wormian (intrasutural) bones; and, often, an enlarged and round sella turcica.

On the left, is a normal neonate in whom both knee epiphyses are present. On the right, is a neonate with congenital hypothyroidism in whom both epiphyses are absent/small.

questions.text: The term “trilateral retinoblastoma” refers to bilateral retinoblastoma + ___________.
questions.solution:
A pineoblastoma occurring in a child with bilateral hereditary retinoblastoma is called “trilateral retinoblastoma.”

In hereditary retinoblastoma (having spontaneous germline RB1 mutation), second malignancies are a major concern. The most common second malignancy is osteosarcoma; other second neoplasms include rhabdomyosarcoma and melanoma.

questions.text: Intramuscular injection of 0.5-1 mg of phytonadione is given to all newborn infants at birth because of a transient deficiency of ________.
questions.solution:
Intramuscular injection of 0.5-1 mg of phytonadione is given to all newborn infants because of a transient deficiency of factor VII.

Hemorrhagic disease of the newborn is caused by a transient deficiency of vitamin K–dependent factors, factors II, VII, IX, and X.

Causes:

  • Lack of free vitamin K from the mother
  • Absence of the bacterial intestinal flora normally responsible for the synthesis of vitamin K.

It is responsive to and prevented by vitamin K therapy (0.5-1 mg of phytonadione).

questions.text: A 49-year-old comes to OPD with a 3-week-old displaced fracture neck of femur. MRI shows a normal femoral head. What is the best management?
questions.solution:
The best management in the above clinical scenario is Mc Murray's osteotomy.

In the above clinical scenario, since the MRI shows a normal femoral head, the patient does not have a significant risk of developing osteonecrosis. But a delay of 3 weeks in the medical intervention can lead to the development of non-union of the fractured ends. Hence the best management is to compress the fractured ends by osteotomy (MC Murray's and Pauwel's) with internal fixation.

If MRI shows the signs of vascular compromise to the femoral head, then along with the reduction of the fracture, the blood supply to the femoral head has to be restored. This is done by vascularisation procedures like fibular bone graft and muscle pedicle grafts.

questions.solution:
The image provided above is that of cock-up splint and is used in radial nerve palsy.

  • Colle's cast:
  • Knuckle bender splint:

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with end-stage renal disease presents with back pain. He gives a history of frequent pathological fractures. Identify the characteristic finding seen in his lumbosacral radiograph given below.
questions.solution:
The radiograph given above shows a Rugger jersey spine which is a characteristic feature of renal osteodystrophy. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of renal osteodystrophy which is caused by hyperparathyroidism secondary to chronic renal disease. 

Rugger jersey appearance is seen due to osteosclerosis of the superior and inferior vertebral endplates. This occurs due to excess osteoid formation by the osteoblasts to counteract increased bone resorption. The term 'rugger jersey’ appearance is used because there are alternating bands of increased and decreased bone density, similar to the jersey of a rugby player.

questions.text: The Kellgren and Lawrence scoring system is based on ___________.
questions.solution:
The Kellgren and Lawrence scoring system uses radiographic changes (X-rays) to divide OA into five categories.

It is the most commonly used system.

 

  • Grade 0: no radiographic features of OA are present
  • Grade 1: doubtful joint space narrowing (JSN) and possible osteophytic lipping
  • Grade 2: definite osteophytes and possible JSN on anteroposterior weight-bearing radiograph
  • Grade 3: multiple osteophytes, definite JSN, sclerosis, possible bony deformity
  • Grade 4: large osteophytes, marked JSN, severe sclerosis and definite bony deformity

 

Other radiological classification systems include Ahlbäck radiographic classification for knee OA.

The Outerbridge classification is based on cartilage damage as observed by arthroscopy.

questions.text: The posterolateral bone grafting technique has been described for non union of-
questions.solution:
• Posterolateral bone grafting is recommended for tibial fractures with infection or extensive bone loss.
  • Reported rates of union after this procedure range from 80% to 97%, with an average time to union of 5 to 7 months.
  • Main advantage: it is a single, non-destructive procedure with a high degree of success.

questions.text: All among the following are ionizing radiations except ______
questions.solution:
• MRI is a technique that produces topographic images by means of magnetic fields and radiofrequency waves.
  • MRI is based on the ability of a small number of protons within the body to absorb and emit radio wave energy when the body is placed within a strong magnetic field.  
  • Alpha, beta, gamma, and x-rays are ionizing radiations. Alpha and beta rays are particulate radiation (Particles) whereas gamma and x-rays are electromagnetic rays (No mass).

Physicists Peter Mansfield and Paul Lauterbur developed MRI-related techniques and they were awarded the 2003 Nobel prize in Physiology and Medicine for their discoveries.

questions.text: A newborn presents with jaundice for 15 days. He has clay-colored stools and hepatomegaly. Ultrasound is performed and shown below. What is the name of the ultrasound finding?
questions.solution:
The newborn with persistent jaundice for more than 14 days, clay-coloured stool, and hepatomegaly is likely to have biliary atresia. The ultrasound confirms the diagnosis by demonstrating the triangular cord sign. 

The triangular cord sign represents the cone-shaped fibrotic mass cranial to the bifurcation of the portal vein. This density is echogenic and represents the fibrous remains of the porta hepatis. A ≥ 4 mm thickness of the echogenic anterior wall of the right portal vein (EARPV) measured on a longitudinal ultrasound scan, strongly suggests biliary atresia.

Biliary atresia is a rare, life-threatening condition in newborns where the bile ducts inside or outside the liver are blocked or absent, preventing bile flow from the liver to the intestine. This leads to bile buildup, liver damage, and eventually cirrhosis if untreated. The exact cause is unknown, but it may involve genetic and environmental factors. Symptoms include jaundice, pale stools, dark urine, and an enlarged liver. Diagnosis involves blood tests, imaging, and sometimes a liver biopsy. The primary treatment is the Kasai procedure, which can restore bile flow, but many children eventually require a liver transplant.

Other options: 

Option A: The falciform ligament sign is seen in the case of pneumoperitoneum. Here, the air outlines the appearance of the falciform ligament as seen in the X-ray below. 

Option C: Double bubble sign occurs due to dilated stomach and duodenum in duodenal atresia. It is seen in X-rays and ultrasound. The following image depicts the double bubble sign. 

Option D: Target sign is seen in infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis. This is due to hypertrophied hypoechoic muscle surrounding echogenic mucosa. The following ultrasound image shows target sign.

questions.text: Anencephaly can be diagnosed by USG as early as ______
questions.solution:
• Anencephaly can be detected as early as 10 to 11 weeks of gestation.
  • Anencephaly is characterized by an open defect in the calvaria and skin, such that the cranial neural tube is exposed. It is a severe defect and is not compatible with survival.

Anencephaly in a foetus showing prominent orbits and an absence of calvarium more cranially - "Frog-eye sign"

questions.text:
Identify the imaging modality given below.

USG- Ultrasonography
MRI- Magnetic resonance imaging
questions.solution:
The image shown in the question is the USG of the neck.

Sonographic examination of the neck shows the thyroid gland, muscles, blood vessels, bony structures or cartilages, and nerves. The thyroid of a healthy patient appears homogeneously echogenic with a uniform echotexture on USG. Lateral to the thyroid, the large blood vessels (the common carotid artery and more laterally, the internal jugular vein) can be identified. In the above image, hypoechoic areas are suggestive of the lumen of vessels seen in the neck i.e common carotid artery and internal jugular vein. 

Other options:

Option B: Fluoroscopy is an imaging modality that allows real-time X-ray viewing of a patient with high resolution. During this procedure, radiologists usually use contrast material (dye) to highlight the area being examined.

Below image shows the fluoroscopy of neck.

 

Option C: The below image shows the X-ray appearance of neck in AP view.

 

Option D: Relative to the neck musculature, the thyroid is hyperintense on MRI images.

questions.text: Linguine sign on breast MRI is seen in _____
questions.solution:
Linguine sign is one of the imaging signs of intra-capsular rupture of a breast implant. After implantation of a silicone or saline breast implant, a fibrous capsule (scar) forms around the implant shell. In an intracapsular rupture, the contents of the implant are contained by the fibrous scar, while the shell appears as a group of wavy lines. This has been termed the "linguine sign" and has been most commonly described with MR imaging.

MRI in intra-capsular implant rupture. The plastic shell of the left breast implant can be seen floating within the silicon, producing a ‘wavy line’ or ‘linguini’ sign.

Multiple hyperintense foci on T2-weighted images are sometimes found within the implant lumen. These findings are referred to as the “salad oil sign” or “droplet sign”.

questions.text: During psychotherapy, the therapist had mixed conscious and unconscious feelings towards his patient. This is known as_____.
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the therapist has mixed conscious and unconscious feelings towards his patient. This is known as counter-transference.

Counter-transference is the positive and negative feelings/emotions expressed by healthcare professionals towards their patients. It is the process of the physician unconsciously displacing onto the patient patterns of behaviors or emotional reactions as if he/she were a significant figure from earlier in the physician's life. Psychiatrists should be alert to signs of countertransference issues like missed appointments by the psychiatrist, boredom, or sleepiness during a session. Supervision and personal therapy can help the psychiatrist recognize and deal with these issues. 

Transference is the positive and negative feelings expressed by the patients towards the healthcare professional. It is the process of the patient unconsciously displacing onto individuals patterns of behavior and emotional reactions that originated with significant figures from the past (generally in childhood). This displacement is onto the psychiatrist in a clinical scenario, who is a parent surrogate. The patient may be angry, hostile, demanding, or obedient to an extreme degree because of former relationships and patterns of behaviors. Failure to recognize this can make the psychiatrist react to the patient's behavior like a personal attack.

These are not defense mechanisms but are commonly encountered during clinical practice or while giving psychotherapy. In an interview, transference and counter-transference are very significant expressions of unconscious processes.

Option C: Dissociation is an immature defense mechanism. In this, involuntary splitting/suppression of mental functions occurs from the rest of the personality in a way that allows the expression of forbidden unconscious impulses without having a sense of responsibility for actions.

questions.text: A patient voluntarily gets himself in the posture as shown and is not changing it. This is called:
questions.solution:
Posturing is exhibited in the above image.

Posturing is spontaneous and active maintenance of a posture against gravity.

Catalepsy is a passive induction of posture held against gravity

Other options:

  • Waxy flexibility: Condition in which a person maintains the body position into which they are placed (passive movement). Slight resistance is felt while moving the limbs.      
  • Negativism: An apparently motiveless resistance to all commands.
  • Cataplexy is a sudden, brief loss of voluntary muscle tone triggered by strong emotions such as laughter. The condition is most commonly associated with narcolepsy.

questions.text: A lady brings her son to you, complaining that the child walks in his sleep every night and always seems confused after waking up. He has no recollection of these events. What is the peak age group in which this disorder occurs?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of somnambulism (sleep walking), and the peak prevalence is between 4-8 years of age.

Somnambulism is a disorder of sleep arousal in which an individual arises from bed and carries out simple to complex motor activities without full consciousness. It occurs in the NREM phase of sleep. 

It is more commonly seen in children, with peak prevalence being between ages 4 to 8 years. It usually resolves after adolescence. It is rarely seen in adults, and has a familial pattern. It may occur secondary to other sleep disorders like sleep apnea. Sleep deprivation, interruption of slow-wave sleep, alcohol consumption, and stress can exacerbate the condition.

During an episode of sleepwalking, the individual may sit up, attempt to walk, or perform semi purposeful actions. They have a blank expression and are unresponsive to communication. Waking them up is possible only with great difficulty.

During the episode, patients can interact with the environment successfully (e.g., avoiding tripping over objects), but can also harm themselves (e.g., walking into the road). Legally, somnambulism is considered a form of automation, and hence doctrine of diminished responsibility applies. Hence, the person is not criminally responsible for his acts carried out during a fit.

 Management:

  • Reassurance
  • Maintaining patient safety during episodes
  • Avoiding sleep deprivation and alcohol consumption before going to bed
  • Antidepressants, relaxation techniques and hypnosis may also be helpful.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is suffering from selective mutism. He is most probably suffering from?
questions.solution:
The child is most likely suffering from a childhood anxiety disorder.

Selective mutism refers to the lack of speaking (being mute) in one or more specific social situations, commonly in school, but speaking well in other situations, commonly at home. The child may be either completely silent at school or maybe just whispering.

The diagnosis can be made when a child has clear communication skills but is being silent in one or more social situations.

Rarely, a child may be silent at home but communicates normally at school.

The first-line treatment includes cognitive behavioural therapy.

questions.text: When will a psychiatrist be more concerned about a patient committing suicide?

choices.text: When in mania rather than depression
At the onset of a depressive episode

questions.solution:
Suicide amongst depressive patients is more likely at the onset and the end of the depressive episode.

During the peak of depressive episode though the desire to die is intense,energy level is low to execute the plan.

For bipolar disorder, the suicidal risk is higher in the depressive phase than the manic phase.

The highest risk of suicide is within a period of 6 months after discharge from a psychiatric facility than when admitted.

questions.text: A patient on prophylactic low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH) is to be posted for surgery. How many hours after the last dose of LMWH can a neuraxial block be safely performed?
questions.solution:
The neuraxial block can be safely performed 12 hours after the last prophylactic dose of low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH).

In a patient who has received a therapeutic dose of LMWH, the block is delayed for 24 hours.

Postoperative LMWH thromboprophylaxis:

  • Remove epidural catheter 2 hours prior to the first LMWH dose
  • If thromboprophylaxis is already started, remove epidural catheter 10 hours after a dose of LMWH. Subsequent LMWH dosing is given 2 hours after the removal of the catheter.

questions.text: What is the maximum percentage of oxygen delivered via a nasal cannula?
questions.solution:
The nasal cannula is a low flow variable performance oxygen delivery system which can provide a maximum inspired oxygen concentration of 40-50 % at flow rates greater than 10L/ min for short periods.

At flow rates of 3-4 L, it can provide inspired oxygen concentration of 30-35%.

Flow rates greater than 5 L/min are not tolerated because of the discomfort associated with this high flow entering the nasal cavity and also due to drying and crusting of the nasal mucosa.

In mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, the percentage of oxygen delivered is 16%.

questions.text: A patient with HIV is on cotrimoxazole prophylaxis. He presents with a 4 cm laceration requiring suturing under local anesthesia. Which of the following local anesthetic agents will not be preferred in him?
questions.solution:
The patient is on cotrimoxazole therapy, a sulfonamide(sulfamethoxazole). The action of sulfonamides is inhibited by procaine and so it will not be preferred in him.

Procaine is hydrolyzed in vivo to produce para-aminobenzoic (PABA) acid that inhibits the action of sulfonamides. All ester local anesthetics produce para-aminobenzoic acid. 

Prilocaine, lidocaine, and bupivacaine are amides and do not interact with sulphonamides.

questions.text: The following can be used for induction of anesthesia in pediatric patients except ______
questions.solution:
Desflurane is a highly pungent gas and so it can produce laryngospasm if used for inhalational induction. Hence it is not used as induction agent.

The incidence of laryngospasm following desflurane induction is almost 50%.

Desflurane is usually used for maintenance of anesthesia only and is of particular value in obese patients, neurosurgical and spinal fusion procedures where rapid awakening is required for neurological function assessment.

Other options :

Option A: Halothane has a sweet odor, is non-irritant, and is non-inflammable. Therefore, it can be used both for induction and maintenance of anesthesia in pediatric patients.

Option B: Sevoflurane is a fluorinated volatile anesthetic and is an ideal induction agent. Its non-pungency and rapid onset make it an excellent choice for smooth and rapid inhalation inductions in pediatric and adult patients

Option D: Due to its second-gas effect, nitrous oxide is mainly used as a carrier gas for other inhalational agents and not given alone.
