questions.text:
The image below illustrates a therapeutic modality for vitiligo. Which of the following are contraindications to this therapeutic modality?
  1. Dysplastic naevus syndrome
  2. Cutaneous T cell Carcinoma
  3. Systemic lupus erythematosus
  4. Dermatomyositis
  5. Polymorphic light eruptions
questions.solution:
The given image shows Phototherapy being used as a treatment modality.

Phototherapy (light therapy) refers to the administration of non‐ionizing radiation (most commonly UV radiation) in a controlled manner to the skin for the treatment of certain skin conditions.

The UVB part of the spectrum is defined as that between 280 and 320 nm and the UVA spectrum is between 320 and 400 nm. UVA is used in combination with an oral or topical psoralen photosensitizer and is known as photochemotherapy (PUVA). UVB phototherapy is preferred to PUVA due to a lower risk of skin cancer.

Absolute contraindications to phototherapy include:

  • Dysplastic naevus syndrome
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Dermatomyositis
  • Genetic skin cancer syndromes (xeroderma pigmentosum, Gorlin syndrome)
  • Severe cardiovascular or respiratory disease

Indications of PUVA therapy

  • Psoriasis
  • Atopic eczema
  • Vitiligo
  • Polymorphic light eruption(for desensitisation)
  • Cutaneous T cell lymphoma

questions.text: Identify the below condition which is present from birth:
questions.solution:
Congenital melanocytic nevus 

  • It may be present at birth or shortly thereafter.
  • They may be small or cover a large portion of the body surface.
  • Large sized (Giant )nevus > 20 cm may predispose to melanoma.
  • Often exhibit extensive nevomelanocytic infiltration of dermis with involvement of underlying adipose and muscular tissue.

questions.text: A patient with a history of fever, myalgia, and severe arthralgia developed pigmentation on the nose after a few days as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given history of fever, myalgia, severe arthralgia, and nose hyperpigmentation (chik sign) points towards a diagnosis of chikungunya. 

Chik sign refers to a central facial pigmentation predominantly on the nose which develops during the acute phase of the disease. It helps in the retrospective diagnosis of Chikungunya infection. It most commonly affects the nose and cheeks. It appears as the fever subsides.

Chikungunya fever is due to infection with Chikungunya virus, spread by mosquitos and direct contact between humans. The Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquitoes are the most common vectors.

It presents as an acute onset of fever, arthralgia, and myalgia with other flu symptoms such as headache, loss of appetite, and nausea. A maculopapular rash develops, which is more pronounced on the trunk. The rash may occasionally progress to petechiae and purpura. 

Diagnosis is mainly clinical, however, a definitive diagnosis can be made by the detection of IgM antibodies in the serum with ELISA or RTPCR.

Treatment is supportive with acetaminophen and NSAIDs. The rash can be managed with saline compresses and emollients. Persistent non-healing ulcers can be managed by topical or systemic antibiotics. Most of the skin lesions resolve within 2 weeks.

Other options:

Option A- Hyperpigmentation of the centrofacial face (nose and cheeks) mimics melasma and may be misdiagnosed if proper history is not taken. Melasma is hyperpigmented macules of the face that increase after sun exposure. 

The following image shows the hyperpigmentation of the face seen in melasma. 

 

Option B- Melanocytic papillomatous nevi are acquired dermal nevi that are very common. They protrude from the skin surface and may be pigmented or skin-colored. Upon histological examination, they exhibit nevus cell nests in the dermis. Therapy consists of excision, shave excision, or laser therapy. 

Option C- Actinic keratosis is a pre-malignant lesion that consists of crusty, scaly patches of skin. It is associated with UV light exposure and is therefore associated with solar damage to the surrounding skin. 

The following image shows the scaly patches of skin suggestive of actinic keratosis of the scalp.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man, who is a known case of lung cancer, presents with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from the chair, combing hair, etc. The following characteristic sign was found on examination. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
The given image shows characteristic upper eyelid lilac erythema/heliotrope rash which is pathognomonic of dermatomyositis.

The other features which further point to a diagnosis of dermatomyositis are

  • Age group 50-60 yrs
  • Proximal myopathy which is manifested as difficulty in climbing stairs, getting up from chairs, lifting hands, etc.
  • Association with internal malignancy

The classic cutaneous signs in dermatomyositis:

  • Facial rash
  • Eyelid erythema and edema
  • Nail fold changes
  • Gottron’s papules
  • Shawl sign which is macular erythema of the upper chest and back
  • Scalp erythema and hair loss
  • Flagellate erythema
  • Mechanic’s hands
  • Poikiloderma
  • Cutaneous calcinosis

questions.text: Cutis marmorata occurs due to ______
questions.solution:
Cutis marmorata is a condition wherein the skin has a pinkish blue mottled or marbled appearance when subjected to cold temperatures. 

  • It is seen throughout infancy and in 50% of children. 
  • It is caused by superficial small blood vessels in the skin dilating and contracting at the same time.
  • Rewarming restores the skin to normal.

questions.text: The Renal function is best assessed by:
questions.solution:
The Renal function is best assessed by Tc-99m MAG3 (mercaptoacetyltriglycine). It is eliminated through kidney as via both glomeruli filtration and tubular excretion.

  • Tc-99m DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) is used to evaluate renal structure and morphology, particularly in paediatric imaging for detection of scarring and pyelonephritis.
  • DMSA is an ideal agent for the assessment of renal cortex as it binds to the sulfhydryl groups in proximal tubules at the renal cortex with longer retention than other agents. Also, it allows better assessment of differential renal function
  • Tc-99m DTPA (diethylene-triamine-pentaacetate) is cleared only via glomeruli with no tubular excretion. Hence used for direct measurement of GFR.

questions.text: According to the Atomic Energy Regulatory Board (AERB) of India, what is the recommended dose limit for occupational radiation workers?
questions.solution:
The recommended dose limit of occupational radiation workers according to AERB of India is 30mSv in any year with an average of 100mSv in 5 consecutive years.

According to the International Commission on Radiological Protection(ICRP), the recommended dose limit of occupational radiation workers is 20mSv per year averaged over 5 consecutive years with no single year exceeding 50mSv.

Recommended radiation dose limit recommended by the various organisations:

Equivalent dose to the lens of the eye 20 mSv per year, averaged over defined periods of 5 years, with no single year exceeding 50 mSv 150mSv in a year 15mSv in a year

After an occupational worker declares a pregnancy, the dose to the embryo/fetus should not exceed about 1 mSv during the remainder of the pregnancy.

questions.text: The Bragg peak effect is pronounced in:
questions.solution:
The Bragg peak effect is pronounced in protons.

The proton is a heavy and charged particle that gradually loses its speed as it interacts with human tissue. It is easily controlled and delivers its maximum dose at a precise depth and can go as far as 32 cm.

The absorbed dose increases very gradually with greater depth and lower speed, suddenly rising to a peak when the proton is ultimately stopped. This is known as the Bragg peak.

The behavior of the proton can be precisely determined and the beam can be directed so the Bragg peak occurs exactly within the tumor site. Immediately after this burst of energy, the proton completely stops to irradiate and the particles come to rest. 

Proton therapy therefore allows to target tumors inside the body, precisely localize the radiation dosage and spare the patient’s healthy cells, offering a much less invasive alternative to treat cancer.

The Bragg curve shown below plots the energy loss of ionizing radiation during its travel through matter.

questions.text: Who is the father of stereotactic radiosurgery?
questions.solution:
Lars Leksell is the father of stereotactic radiosurgery. He was the inventor of radiosurgery.

Wilhelm Roentgen is the father of radiography.

Option B: Thomas Starzl is the father of modern transplant surgery and performed the first human liver transplant.

Option C: The first CT machine used for clinical purposes was developed by the late Sir Godfrey Hounsfield.

Option D: Robert Egan improved mammography technology further by using industrial film that required less X-ray energy and produced better quality images.

questions.text: Doppler effect results from change in:
questions.solution:
• The Doppler Effect results from an apparent shift in sound frequency as sound waves are reflected from moving targets, usually blood cells.
  • In colour Doppler, type of colour represents the direction of flow.
    • Red- flow is towards the transducer
    • Blue – flows is away from the transducer
  • In Spectral Doppler; flow is represented in wave form.
  • Uses of Doppler:
    • Investigation of choice in DVT
    • Investigation of choice in testicular and ovarian torsion
    • Carotid artery stenosis screening, if there is stenosis velocity is increased
    • In pregnancy
  • Umbilical artery Doppler for follow up of IUGR foetus
  • Uterine artery Doppler – Diastolic notch usually disappears after 22 weeks. Persistent diastolic notch in uterine artery after 22 weeks of gestation is a predictor of pre-eclampsia 
  • Increased peak systolic velocity of foetal MCA is an indicator of foetal anemia.
